PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 1.45 p.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MACKLIN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 14 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

(1) Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

(2) Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
(3) In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving 'property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
(4) Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects, namely:
(i) a slowing down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
(5) Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pecuniary Interests of Members of Parliament

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WALSH

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from nine citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That public respect for the Government and the institution of Parliament is diminished by the non-disclosure of pecuniary interests of Ministers of the Government.

In particular, your petitioners call upon the Senate to restore respect for the Parliamentary system by seeking a declaration from the Minister for Communications as to whether he has made the $100,000 repayment due on February 1st 1982.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia:
Concerned about the high price and increased rate of divorce and family breakdown,
Convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and
Believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened
Humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to:
(1) Reject any moves towards divorce by post
(2) Restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or marriage
(3) Protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will
(4) Ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage
(5) Encourage counselling towards reconciliation
(6) Restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown in terms of:
(i) intolerable behaviour;
(ii) desertion for two years;
(iii) separation for three years.

PETITION.TITLE: Church of Mary Queen of Peace, Lithuania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Church of Mary Queen of Peace Klaipeda, Lithuania was the only church permitted by Soviet authorities to be built in post-war Lithuania.
That the church was built by the Catholic parishioners from their own resources and with support from overseas Christians.
That upon completion of the church building in 1960, the church was not allowed to be consecrated and, in 1961 was resumed by the State for purposes other than religious.

That this resumption of the church and the subsequent persecution and arrests of the local clergy and other Christians is contrary to the spirit and the letter of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Convenant on Human Rights.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled request the Australian Government to communicate most strongly to the Government of the USSR the sympathy of the petitioners for the plight of the Lithuanian Christians and ask that the Church of Mary Queen of Peace be restored to the Catholics of Klaipeda for the practice of their religion without interference.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Yugoslavia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are gravely concerned that the Federal Government of Australia discriminates against Croatian migrants in Australia the target of combined Yugoslav and Australian security operations with the express purpose of discrediting the movement for Croatian independence and statehood, and that in so doing it is aiding and abetting the Yugoslav regime in the sentencing and imprisonment of Croatian intellectuals, students and priests and ordinary people in the thousands, the imprisonment of more than two thousand Albanians as a result of the uprising in Kosovo at the beginning of this year, and the murder by Yugoslav Secret Police of more than 70 Croats in Western Europe in the past few years.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate urge the Government that diplomatic relations with Yugoslavia be called into question and discontinued as a sign of protest, and that Australia ask the United Nations General Assembly to supervise a referendum whereby the constituent nations of the so-called Federation of Yugoslavia might vote on the question of secession.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Defence to the statement by the Minister for Defence of 25 March 1980. The Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: Of fundamental importance to our military operations and defence preparedness is an improved availability of resources for such things as spare parts, maintenance and equipment repair, flying hours, steaming time, ammunition holdings and other stores, and higher states of training of skilled manpower. In these respects also we aim to broaden the expansion base and reduce the lead time for movement to a higher state of operational readiness . . .

I now ask: What changes in Australia's strategic environment have occurred that justified the Minister's announcement last week of restraints on training activities and equipment repair, and reductions of fuel and other stock holdings levels, and services and activities, including the Navy's steaming time, the Army's utilisation of its armoured vehicles and service flying hours in respect of the Air Force?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not disagree with the views expressed by the Minister for Defence, nor would he disagree with what Senator Button quoted. The matters in the statement by the Minister for Defence on Thursday of last week to which Senator Button referred indicated that there was some rearrangement of priorities and rescheduling of certain matters in relation to the overall decisions which have been made by the Government in recent months. In relation to manpower, of course, the implementation of the Coldham recommendations added very considerably to the costs of wages and salaries in this year and the purchase of the Invincible requires payments to be made at an earlier date than was anticipated. But, as I said, apart from substantially a rescheduling of payments and a rearrangement to a relatively small extent of some priorities such as those mentioned by Senator Button, the overall commitment of the Government to defence remains undiminished. That is exemplified by the fact that , as the Prime Minister has already said, this financial year there will be in fact a substantial increase in the expenditure on defence. The actual cash spent by the Government on defence this year will be increased by 19 per cent.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister appreciate that this is not really a matter of expense? It is a matter of a statement made by the Minister for Defence in 1980 that flying hours and Royal Australian Navy steaming time would be increased as a matter of Government policy. The question is: What has changed, in terms of Australia's strategic environment, which enables the Minister to say that these things are no longer important in 1982? Let me put it also in these terms: Was the decision which was made in 1980 wrong in regard to Australia's strategic preparedness?

—I thought I made it clear in my answer that we are dealing with matters of degree and, to some extent, a rearrangement of priorities; but there is no disagreement with the broad thrust of the statement that was made by the Minister for Defence in March 1980. As far as the specifics of the reductions of flying or steaming time are concerned, one would have to have regard to the details of the position in March 1980, which was referred to, as against the position today. If Senator Button wants that sort of detail I certainly will refer the matter to the Minister for Defence to see whether he has anything to add to what I have said.
—I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy: Has any assessment been made of energy or power conserved in Australia as a result of daylight saving?
—How can you answer that question?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that the Australian Labor Party would not answer the question by referring to the statistics given by the Labor Minister for Energy in New South Wales who has recently given a specific answer as to what he regards as the quantitative measurement of energy conserved by daylight saving. If the Labor Party--
—How can you do that without notice?

—The honourable senator asked how I can do that without notice. The Minister for Energy in New South Wales, Mr Landa, stated in the Press-I take it that all honourable senators can read-that it was expected that the extension of daylight saving, which occurred in New South Wales and in the Australian Capital Territory in recent times, would save one per cent of energy otherwise used in that period. Indeed, it was estimated that in other States the effect of daylight saving would be a reduction of one per cent in usage of electric energy. I am sorry that Senator Georges rejects the statements of his Labor colleague, but that is for him to judge. That is a measurement in terms of electric energy. One does not know what other consumption of energy may offset it-for example, fuel energy if there is a greater use of automotive vehicles during daylight hours. Fundamentally, it was expected that, with the conservation campaign going on, upwards of 6 per cent of energy could be saved in New South Wales, of which I understand one per cent would be from daylight saving. I think daylight saving is carried out for social reasons as well as for energy conservation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw to the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Defence a statement made by the Minister for Defence on 25 March 1980 when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: There will be 10 additional patrol boats ordered, to meet increased surveillance and patrol requirements.

I draw to his attention also legislation passed in the House of Representatives a fortnight ago which entails increased responsibilities to patrol off-shore rigs following an alteration to Customs legislation permitting direct importing of goods at the rigs. What reduction has occurred in Australian surveillance tasks since 1980 which permitted the Government to announce, as it did last week , that it would not proceed with the acquisition of the first five of the additional 10 patrol boats?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the important matter to be emphasised in relation to this question is that the Government has decided that it will not at this stage proceed with the acquisition of an additional five patrol boats. There has not been a decision, as has been reported widely, that the Government will not proceed with the acquisition of those boats. The decision is simply that the Government will not proceed at this stage. That is part of the point that I was trying to make in answer to Senator Button. There has been simply a necessary rescheduling of purchases and programs and a rearrangement of priorities. There has not been a decision to cancel the acquisition of these five additional patrol boats. There was a decision in the first place-as Senator Elstob's question recognised-to buy the additional patrol boats. There has been a decision not to proceed with the purchase at this stage. The decision to purchase has not been cancelled or reversed.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it not true that Australian Navy patrol boats carry out a lot of surveillance to stop drugs coming into this country? As the Minister has said that at this stage it is not necessary to purchase the five additional patrol boats, does he mean that at this stage there is no need to have surveillance to stop drugs coming into the country? Is there no fear that drugs are coming into this country over the water , something which the Navy would normally stop if it had extra patrol boats?
—I am not saying that at all; nor is the Government saying that. I am simply saying that it has been decided that the acquisition of five additional patrol boats will not proceed at this stage.

—I preface my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate by referring to the many pronouncements in the media by leaders in business and industry that, largely through excessive wage demands, crippling industrial disputes and shorter working hours, Australians are squandering their future. Given the importance to the standard of living of all Australians that our exports remain competitive, is the Government concerned that a lack of national will or pride-call it whatever you like-could be a major reason that we are seen to be placing our future at risk?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have outlined to the Senate the particular difficulties and challenges that Australia faces at this moment because of rising wage demands. The Senate is well aware that in the first half of the 1970s wages rose very rapidly and, indeed, during a brief time in 1974-75 rose by 37 per cent. The effect of that was effectively to cost us out of world markets. In the years that followed the Government tackled inflation in such a way that our trade relations improved to a point where they were better than they had been for some 10 years. But the recession overseas has caused countries overseas to take stock of their cost position. They are now discounting wages. Indeed, trade unions and employees are taking cuts in wages voluntarily in order to keep their countries competitive. The result is that the rate of inflation is falling overseas, whereas in Australia it has not fallen in recent months. The fact is that there is a danger, therefore, that our competitiveness will diminish rapidly unless there is a full understanding of this matter in Australia. I do not believe that the Australian people are incapable of the will or the decision-making ability to tackle this matter, so long as it is clearly understood. Governments themselves, particularly State Labor governments, have been pacesetters in high wage claims. These kinds of things are bad and set a bad example. They will delimit our ability to trade. Senator Walters, therefore, has put her finger very rightly upon one of the major things that are bedevilling Australia at present and will bedevil Australia in the months ahead.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TECHNOLOGICAL CHANGE: EFFECT ON EMPLOYMENT LEVELS

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware that the Australian economy is now generating only half the number of new jobs needed to prevent the level of unemployment rising further? Is he aware also of recent reports of robots playing an increasingly active role in Japanese manufacturing, to the extent that some firms have cut employment levels dramatically and that it is believed that in 10 years half of everything made in Japan will be produced by robots? Does the Minister concur with a report in today's Australian that the new technology of robotics is expected to prove central to the future of Australian industry? For instance, it is estimated that Japanese painting robots can do 1.5 times the work of human painters, seven days a week, 24 hours a day. Given these statements and given the already declining level of job creation in Australia, can the Minister inform the Senate of the steps the Government is taking, or proposes to take, such as long term indicative planning , in order to overcome the effects of the silicon chip and technological change on employment levels?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Siddons's question is really an extension of the question asked by Senator Walters and, indeed, of my answer to that question . Representatives of manufacturing industry and commerce have pointed out to the Government that wage rises and cost pressures of recent times are such that their capacity to employ is being diminished and that, therefore, there will be fewer new job opportunities. That is basic to the effect of rising costs and specifically of higher wages. The primary solution to that problem is to try to get in Australia an understanding such as has been reached and is being reached elsewhere in the world; namely, that there should be some moderation of this upward pressure of nominal wages, which in the end destroys real wages and jobs.

ANSWER.PARA: As I understand the other part of Senator Siddons's question, which referred to robots and silicon chips, the implication is that such introductions will destroy employment. I have to say that every study that has been made over the years, of any authoritative background in terms of the effect of new technology on job creation, has found that in fact technology does not threaten job creation, that what does happen--

TALK.START.PARA: —They are five-year-old studies. You are five years out of date.

—I think the previous Federal President of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Hawke, was on a committee-not five years ago but several years ago-which, if my memory serves me correctly, concluded in part what I have just stated. The fact of the matter is that members of the Labor Party are now saying that Mr Hawke is out of date. I noticed that fact was borne out in the Labor Party ballots the other day-he was very much out of date. The fact is that over the years throughout the world studies have been made of the effect of technology upon job creation. The evidence, which has been very persuasive, has shown that there need not be job displacement in the overall or net sense of job loss but that in fact new technology should create greater opportunities for increasing purchasing power by reducing costs. There should therefore be a wider ability to create more materials and more demands both within the tertiary sector and within ordinary employment. That, I think, still stands in the judgment of those who have expert judgment on this matter.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Can the Leader of the Government in the Senate advise the Senate whether the Government is planning any investigation into the short term effects of the technological revolution that is now upon us? I agree that in the long term new technology does create jobs, but undoubtedly in the short term there will be considerable dislocation. Is this problem being addressed by the Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is normally called structural unemployment-that is, temporary displacement-has been the subject of considerable study by the Government. The Department of Employment and Youth Affairs and other departments have concentrated on this matter. There is a variety of training schemes aimed at giving people new skills. Within the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs and the Department of Education programs are being developed for retraining people who are displaced through structural unemployment so that they are equipped to undertake new and different jobs.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that some banks , building societies and other lending institutions are accepting new accounts in names other than those of the depositors? In some instances these accounts are being used for tax avoidance purposes. Can the Australian Taxation Office place an obligation on these institutions to establish the bona fides of the person opening an account so as to avoid this situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will seek a response from the Treasurer on this matter. I do not think it is anything new that individuals, companies and others open bank accounts under a number of designations. I will ask the Treasurer whether he feels there are implications with regard to the Commissioner of Taxation and whether some response could be given. There are many ramifications, beyond purely taxation measures, in determining the name in which a bank account or a deposit account may be opened. However, as I said, I will seek from the Treasurer a response on whether something is forthcoming.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. In view of the Government's announced reductions in expenditure on defence installations and the follow-on destroyer program, is it still the Government's intention to home port two destroyers and two submarines at HMAS Stirling in Western Australia by 1986?

—The rescheduling of payments and the delays in the purchase of equipment which would otherwise be proceeded with were detailed by the Minister for Defence in his statement on Thursday. I understand that it was an exhaustive statement of what changes are to be made in the defence program. However, I will refer the specific question that Senator McIntosh has asked to the Minister to make sure that a completely accurate answer is given to him.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer . Will the Treasurer take urgent steps to introduce legislation to provide for the apprenticeship scheme run by the Master Builders Association in the Australian Capital Territory to have exemption from payroll tax, similar to that which is available in some States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not aware whether representations have been made directly to the Treasurer on this matter or whether it is under consideration. In any case, I will refer the question to him and seek some response to it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. What is the Government's response to the likely collapse of Americia's most ambitious shale oil project, the Colony development in Colorado, following the withdrawal of the Exxon Corporation? Using that as an example, does the Minister agree that, in times of rising development costs but stagnant oil prices, substantial government assistance is needed if Australian synthetic fuels are to be viable? I ask the Minister whether the Government can see any relevance to the Australian situation in the comments of the Tosco Corporation President, Mr Morton Winston, reported as follows:

QUESTION.PARA: I think (the Colony project's likely collapse) says something about the need for government participation on a sustained and intelligent basis in order to make such a field demonstration on a commercial scale fully viable.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —All of those who have engaged in the pursuit of the technology and the long term commercial development of synthetic crudes have been emphatic that the one stimulus that is necessary is for the price of natural petroleum products to be such that syn-crudes would be competitive with them. It has been indicated in Australia repeatedly that import parity pricing would be sufficient stimulus for that purpose. It so happens that for a short time in recent months-and prospectively for some little time-there has been a very temporary surplus of oil in the world. That surplus will disappear. The goals of the energy program still remain the same. Oil will become scarcer and scarcer in the long term and it will become dearer and dearer. There will be a need for synthetic crudes. In terms of the present surpluses, there is a realisation that there will not be as pressing a commercial need for synthetic crudes in the immediate years ahead as had been thought before. No one is suggesting that in the longer term synthetic crude production will not be necessary.

ANSWER.PARA: The first thing I would like to say in relation to the Colony announcement this morning is that Esso has advised the Government that this will not affect in any way the arrangement that has been made with the Rundle joint venturers. The joint venture contractual arrangements which became effective in March this year commit Esso to expenditures of at least $30m at Rundle over the first three years of a technical investigation program. That will not be affected. Secondly, I understand that a decision has never been made for an immediate go-ahead of the Colony project. I would take it to be a deferral because of the temporary glut. I do not think that anybody within the energy industry anywhere in the world believes that the glut will remain for any real length of time or that the need for synthetics has been removed or put aside for any really long period.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Could the Minister tackle that section of my question that related to the necessity for government assistance in even a country like the United States and apply that example to Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ray will recollect that at the very beginning I stressed that all of the venturers in synthetic products had emphasised that the real assistance that was necessary was in relation to the pricing of natural crude oils so that they would be competitive. There was never any suggestion that other assistance was necessary; nor is there any such indication. The fact is that at a time when the scarcity price of oil is real it is quite clear that the synthetic crude projects will go ahead and be likely to be commercially viable and competitive.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN FOUNDATION ON ALCOHOLISM AND DRUG DEPENDENCE

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Health to the recently published report sponsored by the Social Policy Committee of the Australian Foundation on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence which called for the legalisation of cannabis. I ask the Minister: Is that recommendation contrary to the recommendations of the Williams Royal Commission? Is it contrary to the policy of the Commonwealth Government? Is it contrary to the best interests of the people of Australia? Is the AFADD financed by the Federal Government? If so, to what extent is it financed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crichton-Browne's question is in a number of parts. The Australian Foundation on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence is financed by the Government, certainly as to some of the costs of its federal secretariat. In addition, I believe that it receives funds for the conduct of its alcoholism in industry program, which is one of the constructive approaches to try to ameliorate the effects of alcoholism in the Australian work force. Yes, it does receive funding from the Commonwealth. It is, in fact, a responsible and leading body in the area of drug dependence and alcohol abuse. It tries to express a reasoned view in what are very difficult areas. The Commonwealth Government has responded to the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs, the Williams inquiry, and has announced that it does not intend to alter the laws relating to the use of cannabis. So to that extent there is a Government policy and a Government statement. I know of nothing which would suggest that that policy is about to be changed.

ANSWER.PARA: The recommendations of the Williams inquiry were made in the light of the current knowledge about these different drugs and about their dangers. One of the things that has been needed in this country is a constructive public debate. I think we should welcome anyone who will contribute to that public debate in a way that will help to increase understanding free of hysteria. I think Senator Crichton-Browne has quite properly expressed a concern that there should be no precipitate action in an area of great social sensitivity. But I think the honourable senator would also accept that while AFADD is trying to move the public debate, however carefully, that is to be welcomed. We as individuals do not have to agree with its conclusions or with the different points to which it takes the argument. In past times I have, of course, contributed to this debate through a Senate committee. In answer to the essential part of the honourable senator's question, the Government policy is clear and unchanged and AFADD is funded from the Federal Government for some of its activities at least.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Does Telecom Australia pursue a deliberate practice of restricting the provision of public telephones in new locations? Is it a practice of Telecom to suggest that organisations should lease a red coin- operated telephone when representations are made for the provision of a public telephone in an area where a demand for such public telephones obviously exists? Has Telecom's pursuit of profits made it neglect its obligation to provide acceptable services to the community?

—I answered a question previously-although I cannot recall whether it was in relation to public telephones or posting boxes-when we explored the policy which applied to the provision of some of these facilities to which the public wants access. At that stage it emerged that a policy is laid down which determines-I cannot recall whether it was about posting boxes or telephones-how they are provided and which takes into account the distance people would have to travel to find an alternative, the kind of population demand and so on. The honourable senator's question, however, is about another matter. His question asks whether people are being pressed into using the red phones when, in fact, they want to have public telephones. I will have to approach the Minister whom I represent to see whether he can obtain from the Australian Telecommunications Commission a specific answer to that question and I will undertake so to do.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, the Minister for Finance. Is the Minister glad to hear that the Victorian State Labor Government is embarked on a campaign of austerity, frugality and care with public expenditure for now and in the future? Is this change of direction due to the example of the Fraser Government? Is it because the Victorian Government now understands that there is no Santa Claus or fairy godmother? Can the Minister say whether the impending bankruptcy of the New South Wales Labor Government is also having an effect on the Victorian Labor Government? Finally, does the Minister commend the Western Australian Government for its balanced Budget policies which have assisted in holding the Commonwealth financial line?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not fully aware of the expenditure proposals of the Victorian Labor Government. I have noticed some comments from time to time. I would think that we would need to await its first Budget to see what exactly it will have in mind with regard to expenditure and the raising of revenue because I have also seen some comments about that. I would not assume that any change of direction-if that is what has occurred-in relation to its policy is as a result of watching the expenditure of the Federal Government or the expression of any of our economic attitudes. I also have no comment to make, as far as expenditure patterns are concerned, on the bankruptcy of New South Wales. Perhaps if I were asked to comment on the Western Australian Government I would reiterate some of the statements made by the former Victorian Government; that is, if that Government had had full access to the revenue raised in that State and was not required under existing arrangements to transfer it to other States it may have been in a healthier position.

ANSWER.PARA: I think some parts of the question raise a number of other questions. The governments concerned will answer for their own Budgets and revenue proposals. It remains to be said that the economic direction of Australia ought to be to look at the level of public expenditure and to show prudent exercise in the formulation of the forthcoming Budgets to see that they enhance opportunities for employment and for the growth in the economy that will raise the standards of living for all Australians. Let us wait to see what the forthcoming Budgets of all those States will provide; perhaps then we can compare them with the Budget we will bring down in August.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Communications satisfied that Telecom Australia has justified the progressive closure of telephone exchanges throughout Australia? What criteria were used in assessing those exchanges to be closed? Is it true that in its proposed plan for computerisation of the telephone communications system Telecom has not made provision for additional availability of lines for the 000 emergency service so that calls for this essential service will depend on the availability of the existing lines at the time of any emergency? Has the Department of Communications done any studies into the social implications of the closure of the exchanges? If so, what were the results of those studies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the Chairman of Telecom, Mr Robert Brack, made a statement about future planning in the manual assistance area, and this is the area of concern, I think, to Senator Coleman since these exchanges are being discussed. I commend Mr Brack's statement to her and also table it. I understand that Telecom's objective is to improve services to its subscribers. It is for this reason that it has been trying progressively to upgrade the services available to those who use telephone services in Australia. One of the ways in which it has been doing this is by trying to provide automatic exchanges wherever possible.

ANSWER.PARA: Before the new systems are introduced the impact of the new exchanges is discussed by Telecom with local communities and with its own staff because it is clear that there will be some changes in practice and some people may find some uncertainties with the new arrangements. The present campaign which is being conducted mainly by telephonists has followed such a round of discussions. The observations that have been made about the value of manual telephonists will be taken into account in the decisions that have to be taken. They will not be ignored; they are considered as an important input. It is important, though, to note that more telephone information is available through automatic exchanges than at present is possible under the manually operated system. An automatic exchange gives people extra capacities and extra opportunities. I will have to seek information on one other part of the honourable senator's question-her question about the 000 service. I think I will be able to get an answer on that, and I will seek it from Mr Sinclair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Education been drawn to an article in the Australian entitled 'Witch-hunt over ANU massacre-one in two economics students fall victim to end of year exams'? According to the article, 130 of the initial 452 students who enrolled dropped out before the exams. Can the Minister inform the Senate what steps have been or will be taken by the Department of Education to prevent such disastrous results and waste of taxpayers' money?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the article, but one of the major recommendations in the report of the Williams Committee of Inquiry into Education, Training and Employment, which Professor Bruce Williams brought down several years ago, was directed towards the responsibility to ensure that students do not fail resting not only upon the students and their families but also upon the institutions. A very strong view had been held before that this was up to the student. I remember from my student days the old university song: 'The profs have issued a bold decree that 50 per cent must fail. It might be you and it might be me but it is all to no avail'.

ANSWER.PARA: The Williams Committee did not take that as a useful kind of approach. The Government adopted Professor Williams's recommendation that heavy responsibility to reduce failure rates should be placed upon the academic staff. In my last few weeks of responsibility for the education portfolio I travelled throughout Australia discussing this and other matters with academic staff. If indeed there is this fall-out it is a matter for the particular institution concerned to look at and to be sure that the defects do not lie only on the students' side but also relate to a need for better communication, better counselling and a better relationship in teaching, which might produce less attrition. I feel it is a very sad thing indeed that, very high standards for the higher school certificate and therefore very high admission levels to a tertiary institution having been set, there should be significant fall-outs. If people are capable of tackling the higher school certificate they ought to be able to tackle tertiary education.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. It follows somewhat the question asked by Senator Coleman. I refer to the new Telecom Australia plans to rationalise its activities by cutting back the number of country telephone exchanges. I ask: Is it not correct that this move will result in the loss of some 400 telephonists' jobs in rural areas? Is it true also that the Telecom moves will result in a substantial reduction in localised country services, operated by knowledgeable people, which country areas regard as an integral part of the local environment? How can the Minister in charge of communications-that is, the National Country Party Minister, Mr Sinclair-possibly justify this reduction in services to country people when protests about the proposed reductions are pouring in to members of parliament?

—I think the answer to Senator Gietzelt's question is contained in the answer I gave to the earlier question; that is, that the Government is seeking to provide better service and that, as a step along the way, it has opened up discussions with those staff who might be affected. The campaign which has emerged is as a result of those discussions being opened up. I do not know whether the figure of 400 jobs is accurate. Like Senator Gietzelt no doubt, I have read, seen and heard some of the public statements which have been made, quite properly, by the telephonists to put their case and to have it given some prominence. The Minister has said that the views will be taken into account when the Australian Telecommunications Commission makes the management decisions for which it is responsible. I emphasise again that its duty is to try to give the best service possible to its subscribers. I think Senator Gietzelt is correct in saying that we are all concerned to see that the telephonists who at present hold the jobs are properly treated in any rearrangement that occurs. I will make sure his concern is passed on to Mr Sinclair.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I refer the Minister to the statement on defence spending which the Minister for Defence made in Parliament last week and in particular to the decision not to procure an additional five Fremantle class patrol boats at this stage. Can the Minister advise what adverse effects, if any, this decision will have on the effective and efficient operation of the northern patrol boat bases under construction in Darwin and Cairns?

—Questions were asked earlier today about patrol boats. I do not want to reiterate what I said in answer to them. Specificially in relation to Senator Kilgariff's question regarding the effect of the decision on the efficient operation of patrol boat bases in Darwin and Cairns, it must be remembered that the operation of these bases will be considerably improved by the decision of the Government to acquire 15 patrol craft of the Fremantle class . Those craft will have a much greater capability than the present patrol craft. We have already obtained four Fremantle class patrol boats; they are in operation. We are in the process of acquiring a total of 15 such patrol boats and, as I have said, it has been decided not to proceed with the acquisition of the additional five at this stage. The operational efficiency of the Darwin and Cairns bases will be greatly enhanced by the acquisition of these additional 15 craft which is proceeding.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security and refer to the view held in some sections of the Italian community that we have been rather slow in reaching agreement on reciprocal pension eligibility with Italy. I am fortified in asking the question by Desmond O'Grady's article in the Age today. Firstly, are we responsible for the delay? Secondly-again I am relying on a member of the New South Wales Parliament, the Honourable Franca Arena-if we enlarge the ambit and eligibility criteria, will the inflow of money from Italy to recipients of its social security system in Australia be bigger than the flow of money out of the country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think 'slow' is probably the right word to use with respect to discussions on a reciprocal agreement. That slowness is attributed to the fact that it is a difficult and complex matter made difficult and complex by the fact that Italy, in common with other European countries, has a social security system which is very different from the social security system in Australia. It is difficult to put the two together. That is a difficulty which has recently been faced by Canada. I think Canada took some 11 years to negotiate a reciprocal social security agreement with Italy.

ANSWER.PARA: I have had some discussions with representatives of the Italian Government. Currently Australian officials are talking with officials of the Italian Government. They are working on the facts of the problem and on some of the options which are open to us to meet the deficiencies. It is true, however, that even under the present system there are substantial amounts of money which come to Italian migrants to Australia from the Italian Government in the form of social security payments to which they are presently entitled. In the same way considerable payments are made by the Commonwealth Government to people who were living in Australia, who qualified for a pension and who have returned to Italy. There is already provision for some payment of social security benefits across international boundaries. There are some areas of deficiency and difficulty. Those areas are currently under close examination. It is a matter of considerable difficulty.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. I appreciate the complexities of the negotiations. Except for the recent Cabinet upheaval, did the Minister intend being in Italy to head the delegation? If not, who is the ranking officer leading off for Australia in the discussions?

—It is true that I was to meet with the Italian Minister in Rome on a day when I found myself in the Government party room. However, I am happy to say that discussions were able to proceed between the Deputy Director-General of my Department, Mr Jim O'Connor, and officials of the Italian Government. At that time arrangements were made, which I subsequently approved, for further discussions at official level. A pair of Australian officials, led by Mr Stephen Skehill, recently left Australia and will be holding further discussions in Italy either this week or next week.

—I refer the Minister for National Development and Energy to his statement of October last that a draft for a new River Murray Waters Agreement had been approved, which announcement was of considerable significance and particularly welcomed by South Australia. Is the Agreement yet ready for execution by the Commonwealth and the States? If the Agreement is not yet ready, will the Minister advise the Senate of the parts causing difficulty and when the Agreement is likely to be executed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill quite appropriately referred to the new River Murray Waters Agreement as a matter of significance. It is of great significance to the three States concerned and to the Commonwealth. I remind him that, from the moment we reached agreement around the table, it was decided by the three States and the Commonwealth that it would function as though it had been legally accepted by all four participating governments. So, nothing that has happened in the interim has delayed its implementation. I repeat that it is as though the Agreement has been signed by all four. Of course, the matter had to take legal and legislative form. My last advice was that very considerable progress had been made. I know of no imperative obstacles at all, but I will get the most up-to-date information on the matter and let Senator Hill know.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is it a fact that deferral of planned expenditures for anti-submarine warfare helicopters will mean further delays in the acquisition of these aircraft for the FFGs? Is it a fact that such aircraft are an essential component of the anti-submarine warfare capability of a task force centred on the Invincible? In the absence of such a capability in the foreseeable future, how will the Invincible add to the anti-submarine warfare capability of the Royal Australian Navy?

—The provision of anti-submarine warfare helicopters was dealt with at some length by the Minister for Defence in his statement regarding the Invincible. It is not simply a question of the numbers of such helicopters; it is also a question of their ability to be used in a concentrated way, operating from effective vessels in all circumstances. The decision to acquire the Invincible was influenced very considerably by the fact that the helicopters can be concentrated on a vessel of that size from which they can be used much more effectively than from an FFG. In fact, a larger number of such frigates would be needed to provide even the number of helicopters that can operate from the Invincible, apart altogether from the other operational improvements provided by the Invincible. It is not a question simply of numbers; it is also a question of the way in which they are deployed.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Education: How is it possible for a university to have a deficit in its budget? Is this constitutional? By way of explanation, I say that it is rumoured that the University of Queensland will budget this year for a deficit of $2.5m. Since the Commonwealth provides the funds for tertiary education, does this mean that the Commonwealth will automatically pick up the deficit? If not, how will it be rectified?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first time that such a problem has confronted me. In the four years I had the education portfolio I did not have brought before me the question of financing significant deficits of universities or other tertiary institutions. The normal Bills which come forward to this place and another place for the provision of revenue for such institutions provide an amount of money for the year and not for the offset of any deficits that may be carried over. I am not aware whether the particular university has any private financing which in itself might provide an offset. It is a matter on which I have not specific information. Therefore, I will ask my colleague, the Minister for Education, to look at the matter and obtain the information.
—I wish to ask a supplementary question. What is the precise legal point? Can a university go into a deficit position?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will need to get up to date information. I understood that the universities were required by the Universities Council to live within their budgets. I am not sure what the legal position is when they move outside their budgets. I will seek that information and let Senator MacGibbon know.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, relates to the space shuttle blood experiment of Dr Leopold Dintenfass about which I have asked him in his capacity as Attorney-General in this House on 10 March and also at recent Estimates committee hearings. Is it the case that the blood experiment of Dr Dintenfass has now been bumped, as the terminology goes, from the United States of America space shuttle flight TST10 in early 1983, for which it was originally scheduled, as a result of the continuing failure of the Australian Government-which has been going on since 1978-to sign an agreement on the question of liability in the event of damage being caused by the crash of the shuttle? I ask whether it is the case that when Dr Dintenfass recently phoned the Department of Science and Technology to inquire as to the progress of the agreement he was told:

QUESTION.PARA: Lawyers and typists have more important jobs to do than working on your agreement.

I ask the Minister again: What is the status of this agreement? Will it be signed in the near future? If and when it is signed, will the Government then approach the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in the United States for the reinstatement of the experiment on the 1983 flight?

TALK.START.PARA: —Neither in my capacity as Attorney-General nor as Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology have I any further up to date information in regard to this saga in which Senator Evans is particularly interested. In the light of his question I will make further inquiries both of my Department and of the Minister for Science and Technology and obtain an answer as soon as I can.

—I draw to the attention of the Minister for Finance her current financial statement. Is the Minister concerned at the size of the present Budget deficit? Does she see some immediate relief forthcoming? If so, is there any prospect of the deficit being close to the Government's estimate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I think there is some concern by the Government that, in the final run to the end of this year, it is obvious that the Budget deficit will be greater than was anticipated at the time of the Budget last August. I think it was made clear in a recent statement by the Treasurer that the best estimate of the increase in the Budget deficit at the moment is that it will be about $1,000m at the close of the financial year. I give that figure, stressing the fact that receipts vary from day to day and collections of company tax and other revenue are still likely to be varied from our present expectations. But there is concern that the deficit is greater than that anticipated at the time of the Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: I think we have discussed this matter in some detail at various stages, pointing to the increases in salaries and the reduction in revenue that have arisen in a number of instances during this financial year. However, it is not long now until the end of the financial year when all of these things will be able to be shown more accurately. I simply say at this time that there is concern with regard to the overexpenditure and the under-receipt of revenue. I think the increase of $1,000m that was given by the Treasurer is, at this stage, the most likely outcome of the Budget.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MINISTER FOR COMMUNICATIONS: USE OF VIP AIRCRAFT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Is it a fact that the Minister for Communications asked for a VIP aircraft to fly him from Tamworth to Canberra yesterday morning and that the aircraft developed a malfunction at Tamworth? Did a second VIP aircraft that was sent to Tamworth with a maintenance crew then fly the Minister back to Canberra? Is it also a fact that two commercial flights were available from Tamworth at the time of the VIP incidents?

—Honourable senators will know that where possible Ministers travel by scheduled commercial flights but sometimes it is necessary to seek special arrangements using either the capacity to charter planes or occasionally the services of the Royal Australian Air Force squadron with its special aircraft. Whether my colleague sought a special arrangement to travel by one of the RAAF squadron's planes yesterday is something that only he can answer. Similarly, it will be necessary to refer to him and, I suppose, to the Minister for Defence to ascertain whether there was any malfunction in the aeroplane and whether a second aircraft had to be sent. The normal practice is that Ministers seek the use of those aircraft only when necessary.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday, 27 April 1982, Senator Martin asked me a question concerning transcripts of Senate Estimates and standing committee proceedings. In answer to Senator Martin's question I advise with regard to Estimates committees that draft transcripts are not made available to anybody. The first publication available is the proof daily Hansard. Government departments then communicate with the Hansard office and make corrections to the daily Estimates Hansard for inclusion in the final edition. Committee members may also make corrections to the daily Estimates Hansard.

INTERJECT.PARA: With reference to the standing committees, one draft copy of the draft transcript of evidence is made available to the secretary of the committee concerned. The committee secretary then has sufficient copies for immediate needs printed by the Senate reproduction section. A copy of the draft transcript is forwarded to the witnesses who appeared before that committee for correction of fact and sense. Copies are distributed also to committee members.

Each standing committee determines the terms on which the transcript of evidence will be made available to outside persons and organisations. It is customary for copies of the transcript of evidence heard in public to be made freely available. In due course the draft copy is returned to Hansard with corrections for incorporation in the final edition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to explain an answer which was given by an officer of my Department during Senate Estimates Committee A hearings on Thursday 22 April concerning the provision of a car for Sir Garfield Barwick after his retirement. I am writing to the Chairman of that Committee to explain the matter. But in the light of headlines in the Australian today I will provide information in the public forum. The Chairman of the Committee asked Mr Glare, the officer of my Department:

SPEECH.PARA: Upon what basis are the services of the car provided?
Mr Glare answered:
The car was provided on the instructions of the Prime Minister.

That answer has been represented in the Australian report today as though it were an answer that I gave-that is not the case. More importantly it was represented-I think with some justification-as indicating that it was a decision of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). The fact of the matter is that the Prime Minister wrote by letter to Sir Garfield Barwick on 6 March 1981 informing him of the entitlement. The Prime Minister's letter was based upon a Cabinet decision of 10 February 1981.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you are all guilty, not just the Prime Minister. I ask that the Minister table the document from which he was quoting, including the Prime Minister's letter.

—Well, I was not really quoting from a document at all. I have in front of me a draft of a letter that I propose to send to the Chairman of the Estimates committee. It is not really refined. I will be sending it later today.
—I appreciate that. Will the Attorney-General then be prepared to table the Prime Minister's letter to which he refers?
—I will have to take note of that point. I thought the letter was referred to in the Estimates committee proceedings.

—On 23 February this year I answered a question without notice from Senator Archer concerning unauthorised fishing boats. The question and answer appear at page 233 of Hansard. It has been brought to my attention that part of that answer stated that United States of America fishing vessels are currently licensed to fish in the 200-mile fishing zone, whereas in fact currently no American fishing boats are licensed to fish in the 200-mile Australian fishing zone. Accordingly, I wish to correct my previous answer in which I indicated that we have licensing agreements involving vessels from the United States. In other respects the answer is factual. I say by way of explanation to the Senate that it would appear that the word 'no' was erased from the departmental brief with which I was provided. I apologise if I misled the Senate in that way and I hope that it caused no honourable senator inconvenience.

—On 29 April Senator McLaren asked me a question about the Broadcasting Information Office. I have obtained some information from the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. I am advised that the ABT has reviewed its staff structure and has developed a proposal for a complete reorganisation. The ABT has decided that, within the bounds of staff ceilings and budgetary constraints, its statutory obligations are of paramount priority and that the effective discharge of its regulatory functions will absorb the bulk of its available resources. It is proposed that a new information division of the ABT will perform some of the functions of the BIO in a modified and reduced way and that other functions will be undertaken by State offices.

—On 29 April Senator Keeffe asked me a question concerning the lantern slides in the Charles Mountford collection which dealt with some aspects of Aboriginal life. He asked whether the slides were to be sold privately or whether the Government had taken any action about buying them. I indicated in attempting to answer Senator Keeffe that I thought this was a matter about which a court challenge had been raised. In view of the uncertainty between Senator Keeffe and me I undertook to get further information. As I indicated, the proposed auctioning of the collection of slides was in fact the subject of a court challenge. The Pitjantjatjara Council, acting on behalf of the people whose secret rituals were recorded in a small portion of the slides, sought a court injunction to prevent the auctioning of copies of the slides in Melbourne last month. I have been advised that the application to the court was successful and that an order was given that the sensitive slides, numbering 50 or fewer, be surrended to the Pitjantjatjara Council. I understand that the Council has not yet received the slides. I understand also that the Council was awarded costs of about $1,000.

—by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation. The interjection I made in this chamber on 25 March during Senator Missen's speech about the food in the parliamentary dining room has been blown out of all proportion to its importance. It was in no way intended as a criticism of the professional competence of the chef or his staff. It was a facetious interjection in line with the tone of the debate. I apologise unreservedly to all those who took offence at my interjection.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Ryan proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Federal Government to secure land rights for Queensland Aboriginals and Islanders.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yet again I have to bring before the Senate the plight of Aboriginal and Islander people in Queensland. I have to do so because of the total failure of both the Queensland Government and the Fraser Government to achieve land rights for Aboriginal and Islander people in Queensland. As the Senate is aware, in the absence of Federal Government action, the Senate, with the support of the Australian Democrats, the Australian Labor Party and Government Senators Bonner and Missen, passed legislation which would give Queensland Aboriginal and Islander people land rights to their reserves. However, now that the Bill has been for some time in the House of Representatives, it is clear that the Federal Government has made up its mind that it will not proceed with that legislation. There can be only one reason for its refusal to proceed-that is, the Fraser Government's fear of the Bjelke- Petersen Government in Queensland. The Fraser Government has never at any time shown any willingness to carry out its constitutional responsibility in Aboriginal affairs and stand up to State governments of its own political complexion which are not prepared to ensure the rights of Aboriginal people. In this instance I am very disappointed to have to say again to the Senate that Senator Baume has failed to act in the same way as his predecessors failed to act. He has failed to challenge the Bjelke-Petersen Government's refusal to grant land rights. He has failed to assert the Federal Government's responsibility and he has left Aboriginal and Islander people in Queensland with no hope of achieving anything from either the State Government or the present Federal Government.

SPEECH.PARA: There may be many reasons for the Fraser Government's inadequacy and Senator Baume's inadequacy in particular. Of course, the Government has had other things on its mind. Lately it has been so strife torn and demoralised that as it lurches from crisis to crisis it is not surprising that there is little energy left for it to deal with the really serious issues confronting this country, such as the unresolved question of Aboriginal land in Queensland. As the Government fights for its political life the future of Queensland Aboriginal people may seem of little consequence to it. However, the Government, even in terms of its own electoral health, is making a great mistake in trying to ignore this outstanding moral question. I believe that at the next opportunity Aboriginal and Islander people in Queensland and in other parts of Australia will use their numbers in many critical, marginal seats to demonstrate to the Federal Government that it no longer has their support. I remind the Government that support for Queensland Aborigines amongst a wide range of community organisations, trade union organisations and church groups is growing all the time. The Government is flying in the face of community opinion by refusing to act in this matter.

The motion that I have moved today provides me with my first opportunity in the Senate to discuss the matter of Aboriginal land rights in Queensland since the Queensland Government brought down its long-awaited Aboriginal land legislation on 25 March of this year. Honourable senators will be aware that that legislation has been universally condemned-by church groups, lawyers, the media, of course by the Aboriginal people themselves and by the Labor Party. I remind honourable senators that this pathetic legislation, which solves none of the problems of Aboriginal land in Queensland, is the legislation that Senator Baume , the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, for so long urged us to wait for. For 18 months Senator Baume kept assuring the Senate and me that he was keeping a close watch on the situation in Queensland, that he was negotiating with the Queensland Premier and that we must take no legislative action in this Parliament because the matter would be resolved by Queensland Government action. For 18 months he asked Queensland Aboriginal and Islander people to do nothing in defence of their situation.

During those 18 months when he assured us that constructive negotiations were taking place, he laid down four principles which he said the Federal Government would require to be satisfied by the Queensland legislation. The four principles -I am sure honourable senators must nearly know them off by heart by now, we have heard them so often-were that the integrity of the present reserve boundaries be maintained, that there be secure tenure for occupants and preservation of their rights to use the land, that local communities play a significant role in the management of the reserves, and that there be full consultation with Aboriginal and Islander people before any decisions were made. It will be clear to honourable senators and to the public that the Bjelke- Petersen legislation satisfies not one of these criteria. Yet, Senator Baume has taken no action. Senator Baume has even stated that the Queensland legislation represents significant advances. How can he expect to retain any credibility in his portfolio when he lays down the criteria which he says his Government will insist on and then none of them are met? Yet he still expects Aboriginal and Islander people to accept this legislation.

If it is Senator Baume's belief that the Queensland legislation represents a significant advance, or any kind of advance at all, then that belief is shared by nobody else in this country. For example, Queensland Anglican and Roman Catholic bishops were concerned enough about the situation to seek independent legal advice. They engaged a Melbourne barrister, Mr Frank Brennan, to analyse the Queensland legislation. I have a copy of that report. I will draw the attention of the Senate to relevant sections of it. For example, it states:

. . . the country reserves (of which there are at least 28, accommodating 20-30 per cent of the State's aboriginal and islander reserve population) are not to be affected in any way by this legislation and they are not to receive the benefit, if any, of any deed of grant in trust.
Another point states:

The Governor-in-Council may exclude from the grant ways of access, ' improvements the property of the crown' such as hospitals, police stations and their surrounds. It may also exclude from the grant an area of land . . . which need not be described by locality but which will remain available for public purposes generally.
A third point states:

The boundaries of the community reserve lands could be varied at any time by order of the Governor-in-Council freed from any parliamentary scrutiny whatsoever. The Governor-in-Council could also vary the purpose for which any land was granted.

And so on. There is a disallowance procedure available for any decision of the Governor-in-Council. But, of course, that disallowance procedure is available only to the Queensland Parliament. One can hardly imagine the Queensland Parliament, as it is currently constituted, disallowing any decision which the Government wanted. It is an impossibility. This is not a proper provision of parliamentary scrutiny. That disallowance procedure, if it were to have any effect at all, should be a disallowance procedure by the Federal Parliament. The report continues:
A Community Council, if and when appointed trustee of land, could be removed as trustee by the Governor-in-Council if it is of opinion that such a removal would be in the public interests. . . .
A Council will be able to lease plots of land or houses to individuals, groups or families. . . .
The Minister for Lands is empowered to require a Council to charge the highest rent which can reasonably be obtained.
The Minister for Lands has the discretion to allow or disallow residents to enter into mortgages. . . .
The Council has no power to allow people to roam, hunt and gather for more than a month without the prior written consent of the Minister for Lands.
No provision has been made to guarantee traditional hunting, foraging and fishing rights.

The security of tenure and integrity of reserve boundaries are no more assured by deeds of grant in trust under the Land Act with proposed amendments than are aboriginal lands at present. There is no legal, workable check on the unfettered discretion of the Governor-in-Council proposed.
Mr Brennan concludes:
The full enjoyment of the land and the free exercise of Councils' powers will be more dependent on ministerial goodwill than on the provisions of law.
The rights enjoyed by the occupiers of the land will be significantly less than those enjoyed by most landholders in Queensland.

I hope that when the Minister replies to my matter of public importance he will take up these legal points which have been made and which, in my view, are unarguable. It is very clear that the legislation is a total failure. That opinion, of course, was backed up by an opinion from Mr Bill Pincus, leader of the Bar Association of Queensland. His conclusions stated:

My response . . . is that no security is offered and, as to the second, no question arises as to the security offered being guaranteed by Act of Parliament . If there was a genuine intention of giving security of tenure, it is manifest that that intention has by no means been achieved in the Bill placed before me.

The failure of the Queensland legislation to respond to the wishes of the Aboriginal people of Queensland or, indeed, to Senator Baume's four principles has thus been confirmed. The Queensland bishops condemned the legislation yet Senator Baume was too weak to do more than put out a statement saying that whilst the Commonwealth Government had some 'particular concerns'-we might learn what they are in the course of this debate-the legislation represented ' significant advances'. The National Aboriginal Conference, elected by Aborigines to advise the Federal Government on Aboriginal matters, has also condemned the Queensland legislation and supported and called for Federal Government action to secure land rights. Of course, Senator Baume not only ignores the NAC's advice; he can hardly find the time even to listen to it. No wonder the NAC, the Government's own national advisory body on Aboriginal affairs, has called for the resignation of Senator Baume. But perhaps Senator Baume, who is smiling across the chamber now as though these matters are of no concern to him, feels that he does not have to spend time with Aboriginal organisations any more because he may be reshuffled out of the portfolio by the end of the week.

I remind honourable senators and the Government in particular of the wide- ranging support there is for Federal Government action to provide land rights for Queensland Aborigines. In 1978 the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs supported Commonwealth action. The World Council of Churches team which visited Australia in 1981 identified land rights as a prerequisite for any significant advances for Aboriginal people and recommended Commonwealth action. The major Queensland church groups-including Anglican, Catholic and Uniting-have all supported Commonwealth action in the absence of any satisfactory State action. So it goes on. A survey last year of Torres Strait Islanders reflected the findings of every unbiased poll ever taken amongst Queensland Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders-overwhelming support for land rights.

These people have now turned to the Federal Government to satisfy their demands and needs. Their elected body, the NAC, has asked the Government to act. It has already the support of some overseas leaders-for example, Father Lini of Vanuatu -and is seeking more overseas support to increase international pressure on the Commonwealth Government to carry out its responsibilities. Yet, instead of paying heed to the Aboriginals, the Senate, the churches and even the international community, the Federal Government has chosen to take the line of least resistance and acquiesce to the proposals of Premier Joh Bjelke-Petersen. I remind the Senate that he is a man who in New Zealand this week described Australian Aboriginals as:
. . . very wealthy people, like the Sheiks of the Middle East . . .

He went on to say that the Aborigines 'already own and control vast areas of land'. That is a statement from a man who is unwilling to give the Aborigines the less than 2 per cent of Queensland to which they want title. Yet this is the man that Senator Baume says we must support and whose legislation is acceptable. The Premier has made it abundantly clear over the last 12 months that he is working against Aboriginal rights and especially against Aboriginal land rights in Queensland. His behaviour has been a litany of breaches of faith with the Aboriginal people. First he labelled the World Council of Churches as communist because it brought to light the unacceptable living standards of Aboriginal Australians and supported land rights. More recently he claimed that the land rights movement was a Soviet plot. Premier Bjelke-Petersen claimed in the Queensland Parliament that the land rights movement was aimed at obtaining large sections of the northern part of Australia for use by communist governments to train people of non-saxon races in guerrilla warfare. This is the man whom Senator Baume and the Commonwealth Government back up in the matter of rights for Queensland Aborigines.

There was also the episode of the Premier claiming to have information that the Queensland Aborigines were going to Libya to train as terrorists. What happened to that bizarre, insane claim? An investigation by the Department of Foreign Affairs found no evidence to support the Premier's allegations-of course. In other words, it was simply another mischievous attempt by the Premier to discredit those working towards land rights. Why is not the Fraser Government challenging these fanatical and mad claims by the Premier of Queensland? It remains silent in the face of those claims. It allows these absurd myths to be perpetrated through the media with very few or very weak attempts at correction.

On a more concrete level, the Queensland Government has just refused to transfer a second pastoral lease to the Aboriginal Development Commission. The case relating to the Queensland Government's failure to transfer a pastoral lease at Archer River to the Aboriginal Development Commission is still before the High Court of Australia. The Queensland Government has now confirmed its racist stance by refusing the transfer of a second pastoral lease. So much for the Premier's claim that Aborigines are treated just like other Queenslanders. Where is an example of the Government holding up the transfer of a lease to any white property owner in Queensland? It simply does not happen. Of course the Premier objects to any public money being spent on restoring land to the dispossessed indigenous people of Australia. Senator Bjelke-Petersen has recently told us that the money would be better spent on roads.

That series of quotations and references to the Premier of Queensland should remind the Senate of the calibre of the State Government which Senator Peter Baume and his Government are now backing. I wonder whether Senator Peter Baume read an article by Stephen Mills in the Age of 2 April this year entitled 'None from four near enough for Baume'. I think this article very accurately described the Minister's response to the Queensland Government's action when it stated that he appeared fiercely determined to be conciliatory in his response to the legislation. The fact that not one of Senator Peter Baume's four principles had been satisfied in the Queensland legislation did not prevent him stating the belief that the Queensland Government acted in good faith and that it would administer its new law in the spirit of secure land tenure. How can the Minister expect honourable senators, who have been subjected to those kinds of performances from Bjelke-Petersen over the last 12 months, to credit him with any good faith in this matter? We do not.

Meanwhile, of course, as the land problem remains unresolved the Commonwealth Games draw closer. In the 18 months Senator Peter Baume has had available to him he has achieved nothing towards the resolution of the Queensland situation. During that time, as everybody knows, the racial tensions in Queensland have escalated and the State Government, in response to this, has typically introduced draconian security laws for the Commonwealth Games which are, of course, laws which will threaten the civil liberties of all Queenslanders. The Federal Government has acted irresponsibly in not settling the issue before the Games. By not acting, the Federal Government is acquiescing in a situation which may lead to violence.

I make it quite clear at this stage that the attitude of the members of the Australian Labor Party is that we want the Games to proceed peacefully. We do not want to see violence at the Games over the issue of land rights, but we must accept the legitimacy of the claims by Aboriginal activists that their needs are being totally neglected and ignored, first, by the Bjelke-Petersen Government and, second, by the Fraser Government.
