The way to resolve this crisis is clear and the Federal Government has to do very little to settle the land question before the Commonwealth Games, thus removing the need for any protests, peaceful or otherwise. All the Fraser Government has to do is allow the passage of my private member's Bill through the House of Representatives and thus indicate to the people of Queensland that it is prepared to take legislative measures to secure land rights.

The Aboriginal and Islander people of Queensland are asking for very little; they are asking for freehold title-secure title-to less than 2 per cent of the State of Queensland. They are asking for title to land on which they have been living for some generations now and which is not being used for any other purpose. The granting of title would not involve any disruption to other land holders or to the State Government. It would not cost, in fact, the State Government one penny to allow those reserves to become Aboriginal land. It is disgraceful that the Bjelke-Petersen Government made the pathetic lease offer. It is even more disgraceful, I believe, that the Fraser Government and its Aboriginal Affairs Minister, Senator Peter Baume, refused to use the powers of the Federal Parliament to secure this transfer of title which every decent and fair-minded person in Australia believes ought to happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — We are discussing a matter of public importance put forward by Senator Ryan which refers to the failure of the Federal Government to secure land rights for Queensland Aboriginals and Islanders. I spoke on this issue in the adjournment debate in the Senate on 21 April, the first opportunity after the Queensland Government enacted its promised legislation. I wish to refer again to some items I raised in that debate. Queensland has an Aboriginal and Islander population of about 60,000 people. The Department of Aboriginal and Islander Advancement, the DAIA, estimates that half that population lives in the State's urban centres. Indeed, about 15,000 Aboriginals have, with the assistance of DAIA, transferred to urban areas within the last 14 or 15 years. Other Aboriginals and Islanders live on reserve land throughout Queensland. Reserve land is of two kinds: The community reserves and the so-called country reserves. I wish to refer to that again in a moment because it is extremely important in terms of the legislation that the Queensland Government brought forward.

SPEECH.PARA: The Queensland Aboriginals, as has been the case with their brethren in all other States, have been waiting, not for a couple of years, not for three or four years, but for hundreds of years, for justice in regard to this matter. Let us look at what has happened in Queensland within the last 25 years to see whether Queensland Aboriginals ought to feel secure in what is going on. For example, within the last 25 years the Weipa reserve has been reduced from 350, 000 hectares to 125,000 hectares to accommodate the Comalco Ltd mining interests ; the Mapoon mission has been closed and its residents moved to Bamaga-of course , some were moved south to Weipa; and attempts have been made to move the people of the Lockhart River area to Bamaga. These are only a few of the major intrusions the Aboriginal people have suffered on the security of their homelands. In the past the Aboriginal people in Queensland suffered probably the most organised attempt anywhere in the civilised world to divest people of their homelands by moving them forcibly from where they had their roots to places hundreds of miles away. That type of activity has not ceased within the last few years. To seek for legal security is vitally important-not words but legal security; not promises but legal security.

Let us look at the issue I raised a moment ago. On 31 March 1980-these are the latest figures I could obtain-DAIA estimated that 9,616 Aboriginal reserve residents were accommodated on 12 reserve sites set up under the Aborigines Act 1971-1979. About 7,000 Torres Strait Islanders lived on their islands and that arrangement was established under the Torres Strait Islanders Act 1971-1979. Reserve communities have their own councils and have been provided with managers , courts and police. The legislation that the Queensland Government brought in relates to those reserves. All other Aboriginal residents live on what are called in Queensland 'country reserves'. These reserves are not subject to the Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders Acts. They are mostly located on the outskirts of Queensland country towns.

In August 1981 the Queensland Government Printing Office produced a map for the DAIA marking 29 such country reserves. The DAIA annual report of 1980, which is the last report to give population figures, stated that the community population in department and church communities in the Torres Strait area and on country reserves was of the order of 30,000 individuals. As it is generally agreed that the Torres Strait Islander population is no more than about 7,000, this figure suggests that there is probably a country reserve population of approximately 23 ,000 Aboriginals. The National Aboriginal Conference has calculated that some 9, 000 people are associated with these reserves; DAIA has estimated it to be about 8,000 and a Queensland Government Minister recently estimated it to be about 200 -presumably he never leaves Brisbane. The point I am raising-it is an extremely important one-is that those people have not been affected by the Queensland legislation and we must pay attention to their needs. I believe it is essential that the Commonwealth Government enact legislation to take account of those 30, 000 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders on country reserves.

Let us return now to the legislation that was brought in by the Queensland Government. In a Press release of 1 April 1982 the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) indicated that he had some reservations in relation to the procedures outlined in the legislation and questioned the type of protection actually offered the people in Queensland. The Queensland Premier has made a number of promises about that piece of legislation. For example, he said:
Before any draft legislation goes before Parliament it will go before the Advisory Councils for discussion . . .

The advisory councils were set up by the Queensland Government under section 33 of the Aborigines Act 1971-1979. They were in agreement on the issue. I will read from two of the resolutions they passed. One states:

The Island Advisory Council constituted under s. 49, Torres Strait Islanders Act 1971-1979 conducted an exhaustive survey of Torres Strait Islanders and recommended to the Premier: 'That Torres Strait Islanders be given inalienable freehold title to all land presently designated Reserve Land under the Queensland Land Act . . .

That seems to be a fairly unequivocal proposition from the Torres Strait Islanders themselves. It was recommended that they be given 'inalienable freehold title'. Again, the Aboriginal Advisory Council working party recommended, and the Council in substance adopted, the following proposal:
'Current Reserve Lands should become perpetual leaseholds under the act of Parliament with an Aboriginal and Islander Commissioner to hold the leases in trust for the communities.

The legislation which was enacted-on 21 April I detailed the appalling problems involved with that legislation-was brought in by the Premier. Senator Baume and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) described the Premier's announcement as ' a good package' because it gave 'ongoing title'. As I outlined on 21 April, the major problem is concerned with the section about for how long and by what methods titles may be taken back by the Queensland Government. The deeds of grant in trust are governed by Part XI of the Land Act 1962-1981 and are created by that section. I refer to existing Aboriginal and Islander reserves. These reserves may be revoked by the Governor-in-Council for any reason thought desirable. I raised a contentious matter on 21 April. I refer to the Hansard of that date, which records my quoting the Minister as having said:
That may be normal in Queensland.
The Minister interjected:
One of the Acts, Senator.
I replied, referring to the Acts being amended:
There are two Acts, the Land Act and the Forestry Act.
The Minister then said:
I said it was normal for the Land Act.
My response was:
You did not say the Land Act, Senator.
I will quote from the Minister's Press release in which he referred to the Commonwealth Government having reservations about the Queensland legislation. The Minister stated:
This may be the normal procedure in Queensland.

The reason I raise that is that the Act which was used to bring in the legislation was the Forestry Act. It may be of interest to this Senate and to the rest of Australia that Queensland flora and fauna now have in place far better security arrangements than has the Aboriginal people's land under those Acts. Under those Acts, State forests and national parks cannot be revoked until Parliament is given the opportunity to scrutinise the proposal. What do we propose to do with Aboriginal lands? They will be removed and when Parliament gets around to it-the Queensland Parliament will not be meeting for another four months-it can do whatever it likes. If one scrutinises the legislation in Queensland one will notice that the Parliament does not even have to refer to the proposal. I am sure that Senator Jones, who was a member of the State House, will be able to point to a number of instances in Queensland legislation in which the Queensland Parliament has totally ignored ever looking at any action which has been taken by the Governor-in-Council although it is specified in legislation that it should do so. It is an extraordinary situation that the legal security of the lands for Aboriginal people should be treated less highly than the flora and fauna of that State. That is the situation we have reached and the situation that Senator Peter Baume believes is a reasonable package.

In the Press release of 1 April, to which I have referred, Senator Peter Baume admitted that the Commonwealth Government had reservations about the Queensland legislation and he said that he had some particular concerns. One concern related to the section to which I have just referred-the fact that land could be resumed before Parliament had a chance to exercise its judgment, which is as far as we are able to go in giving security of land in Queensland. At least the entire Parliament, not the Governor-in-Council, not the Premier and not the Cabinet, ought to have the final say. Let only parties such as the Minister's party-the Liberal Party-which has a policy in Queensland governing this matter, face up to the issue in Parliament rather than saying that they were steamrolled in the Cabinet by weight of numbers. Let us not let the Liberal Party in Queensland off the hook so easily, if that is what the Minister is attempting to do.

The Minister, in his Press release, gave an unequivocal guarantee that the Commonwealth would act to remedy any transgressions of principles of security of tenure. I believe that we have to welcome that unequivocal guarantee.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be very busy then, won't it?

—Yes, but I ask: Why must the Commonwealth give an unequivocal guarantee? If we look back over recent years, not only to when the Minister's Government has been in power but also to when the Australian Labor Party was in power, what did the Commonwealth Government do? Why ought Queensland Aboriginals to be secure in any guarantee given by any parliament of this country until they have managed to get it secure, in legislation, so that the Parliament must act to take something away? Why do we have to rely upon a promise that something will be done--
—After the transgressions.

—After the transgressions? The Minister has asked the reserve residents in Queensland to rely, first, on the State Government's good will and, secondly, on the Commonwealth Government's determination to see that principle is maintained. Neither of those parliaments has backed up those assertions by force of law. Why? How can Aboriginal people feel secure if neither Parliament will enact legislation to fulfil those types of promises and assurances? Why unequivocal guarantees and not unequivocal legislation? Surely it is testing the patience of the Aboriginal people in Queensland to breaking point to say to them yet again: 'Rely upon us. If it comes to the crunch we will do something'. Surely such reliance is not easy for them to accept at a time when the good will and determination of neither government has resulted in legislation guaranteeing the security which both governments have promised but which again has not been forthcoming.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats believe that the House of Representatives now has a moral obligation to enact the legislation which was introduced into this chamber by Senator Ryan and passed by the Senate. That legislation will at least go part way towards giving the Aboriginal people in Queensland some force in law so that they do not have to rely upon the word of a white man. Whey should an Aboriginal rely upon the word of a white man if white man will not put it in writing? White man has given his words for a long time in this country and all we have got again are more words. The Aboriginal people want legislation; they want their land. The very least that this chamber can do is support the matter of public importance brought forward by Senator Ryan and support my notice of motion that this chamber again request the House of Representatives to deal urgently with a Bill which was sent from this place some weeks ago. Unless it does that I believe the types of propositions that Senator Ryan canvassed in her speech will come about. It will be a tragedy, people will be forced on to the streets to demonstrate for something that they feel so dearly about. The people again will be forced to take that type of action. If they do the people who will stand condemned will be members of this Parliament who have failed to grapple with the Parliament's constitutional rights, its constitutional powers, and pass legislation which will put on the legislative books of this country firm and unequivocal guarantees for the future of those lands, that small percentage of the Queensland land mass, which the Aboriginal people have been calling their home for some 100 years. They are not their total homelands, only that little bit left. That is all they are asking for. They have said time and time again: ' Are we asking for too much just to ask for this little bit which we have left?' Surely they are not and surely at last someone can respond to those types of cries that are being made so often in this country to give Aboriginal people that-and in firm, secure and legislative form.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Thomas) agreed to:
That so much of Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs from speaking for 20 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance which has been submitted to the Senate by Senator Ryan in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Federal Government to secure land rights for Queensland Aboriginals and Islanders.

I must start by contrasting the measured and thoughtful contribution made by Senator Macklin, in which I thought he addressed some of the issues, with what I thought was a quite hysterical and ideological presentation by the proposer of the matter of public importance. I hope that those who have listened to the debate will have noted the difference in approach and the way in which the matters have been dealt with. It is not even clear what Senator Ryan means by the failure of the Federal Government to provide land rights. Does she mean the granting of title to reserves? Does she mean the machinery for transferring title to other lands?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is all in my Bill. You know what it is. It is all provided for in the Bill.

—The honourable senator, having had her say, now comes out with this hysterical noise. Does she mean compensation for past dispersal? Does she mean the provision of an economic base from which Aboriginal self-management may be pursued? What are land rights anyhow? I have studiously avoided using such terms because they do not really help us. The term 'land tenure' is more helpful especially in talking about the Queensland situation. I can converse with Senator Macklin because he is talking about land tenure. The term 'land rights' has been used to describe a multitude of land holding arrangements in different States. Senator Ryan could have been talking about the Pitjantjatjara model in South Australia, which is one model. She could have been talking about the Northern Territory model, which is the one that she is touting around. She could have been talking about the transfer of land to the Aboriginal community at Cape Barren Island in Tasmania. She could have been talking about the Western Australian model, which has provisions similar to the one for flora and fauna in Queensland under which land reserved for Aboriginals, though it remains Crown land, cannot be touched without prior approval of that State Cabinet. She could be talking about the situation proposed for New South Wales whereby the whole 109 square kilometres held on behalf of Aborigines in New South Wales will eventually be transferred from one Aboriginal land holding body to a series of others. That has actually been called land rights in the State which I represent and which you represent, Mr Deputy President. Each of those models is different from the others. It does not help the debate or communication when an honourable senator talks in those terms. Does she mean a grant of deed in trust, as in Queensland? The term 'land rights' could be used for any of these phrases. Why does she stick to the rigid concept of land rights as per the Northern Territory model, which is the one she uses?

SPEECH.PARA: Surely I just have to ask: What are the goals we are trying to satisfy? What are the goals that I have been trying to satisfy? What are the several ways in which we might move to achieve those golas? First, may I suggest that it is inappropriate to try to look to an imposed solution from a central government and hope that that will resolve the problem which faces Aborigines in Queensland . The Government has always said that there is an initial issue to be resolved- whether Commonwealth power should be used as a first step to achieve a Commonwealth solution which is imposed upon the States or whether the State should try to act and the Commonwealth should use its powers only if necessary. It is our belief that imposed solutions have less chance of being successful. An imposed solution would carry with it the risk of losing State services. It would carry with it the chance that the State would withdraw from the services of roads, water supply, power supply, schools, police and hospitals-all matters which are under State control, all matters which a State can deliver or withhold . One would run at least the risk-and I put it to Senator Macklin just as a matter to be looked at-of creating Aboriginal enclaves from which State services had been withdrawn and into which we would then have to move and administer. That does not mean that one would not do that but one would have to take into account the loss side of any action one tried to initiate. Of course, incidentally this would promote a whole series of legal challenges which, although they may have to come, would leave the waters muddied for some time.

Senator Macklin said something else to which I want to refer. All governments since 1967-Labor and Liberal governments-have chosen not to impose land rights for Aboriginals on State governments. The Labor Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in 1973, the Honourable Gordon Bryant, actually spoke on this matter. He said in 1973 that he was an advocate of persuasion first and that only if persuasion failed should counter-attacking legislation, overriding legislation, be introduced. Despite talk of possible Commonwealth intervention, despite talk by the Labor Government of that day that it would do something-talk that went on for two and a half years-the Labor Government shelved any ideas of imposing land rights in Queensland in 1975. Yet this is precisely the course that Senator Ryan wants us to now take. I just do not think she understands that it would not benefit Aboriginal people. That is my concern. I come back to Senator Macklin. By contrast, he has urged all the time that we need to seek the benefit of the communities. That is the only goal we are seeking.

Of course, land rights, land tenure and land solutions are only part of the problem. Whatever form it takes, the obtaining of land rights-however one uses the term-is not an end in itself. Its value lies in the fact that it may be an important step-one which the Government wishes to see achieved in Australia in ways which are appropriate to local situations-towards Aboriginal advancement on a whole lot of fronts. The questions we must ask are about the social and economic conditions of Aboriginal people, about the place they have in Australian society and about the opportunities they should have. The granting of land tenure alone will not solve the problems they face. As I have said, an imposed solution such as is being promoted at this stage may in fact make them worse, at least in the short term.

The matter of public importance refers to a failure by the Federal Government to secure land rights. What failure? What failure has there really been? I remind honourable senators that in January 1981 we faced a situation where the Queensland Government was proposing to repeal the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders Act and put nothing in its place. It proposed to take away the administrative structure and it was said at the time by politicians in Queensland that the reserves would be abolished and that Queensland Aboriginals should be like other Queenslanders. Six months later we had a suggestion that leases would be given for a period of 50 years and maybe renewable. We have reached the situation now where we are way down the track, where Queensland, in terms of its attitude and its willingness, has come light years from the position it set out in January 1981 and in June of that year. Those are facts. Whatever Senator Ryan thinks failure means, she should know by now that the Queensland decision, when announced early in March, represented the most significant progress we have seen from that State in our lifetime. It represents significant progress in security of land tenure for Aboriginal and Islander people. It was more than many people expected, given the number of announcements by the Premier. Let me say again that the Commonwealth was seeking, and saw as being most productive a Queensland solution in the first place to what is a problem of interest to all Queensland citizens.

I know that there are points of legal difficulty involved and I am aware of the work of Mr Frank Brennan. I am aware of the statements of Professor Garth Nettheim. I am aware of the opinion of Mr Pincus. I thank honourable senators for bringing these out during the debate. They are not the first to have noticed them, but those reservations do not mean that the program has been a failure. It is very interesting to note that, while Senator Macklin was willing to concede the fact of the Commonwealth guarantee, Senator Ryan chose almost to ignore it and to put it aside.

I want to discuss a little the question of the grants of deed in trust. If we look at the Queensland Land Act we find that these deeds of grant are not unusual. They exist in Queensland in a variety of situations. If we look at section 5 of the Act we will see that it shows that the grants of deed in trust can be made, are made and have been made for a wide range of public purposes. It might help honourable senators if I table a list which shows some of the many purposes-maybe 50 purposes-for which these deeds of grant are made. I table the document. This is an established form of land tenure in Queensland. It is not new. It provides, for example, for the holding of land by many charitable and public organisations. Many of them hold property under deeds of grant in trust in Queensland. Of course, for them also there is the threat of losing their land if the strict letter of the law is applied. They include the home for the aged and infirm in Coolangatta, the trustees of the Queensland Police Citizens Youth Welfare Association, the Saint Mary's Home and Female Refuge in Brisbane, the reserve for the racecourse and the showground in Gympie, the Morningside Recreation and School of Arts in Brisbane. I can go on and on. All of these organisations hold the land which they use and which their communities value under identical kinds of deeds of grant. Is anyone saying that they feel insecure? They do not feel insecure. Whatever they have, they do not have the guarantee which the Commonwealth has given and which the Commonwealth has made available precisely to overcome the insecurity which some people feel and to overcome the strict points of law which have been raised by some commentators. That the Commonwealth has given that guarantee puts the lie completely to any assertion that there has been a failure on the part of the Commonwealth to apply itself to or to resolve this situation.

In the case of Aboriginal land, the Commonwealth has given an unequivocal guarantee to stand behind the stated intention of the Queensland Government. The Queensland Government stated that intention in its Press release of 1 March. It put out its Press release saying what it intended should be the consequences of its action. Our guarantee is to ensure that that intention to provide security of tenure and integrity of the reserve land-those are the words used by the Queensland Government-is preserved. That is our unequivocal guarantee. The Government has said that, if there were actions which transgressed that guarantee or which indicated an unreasonable use of the discretion in the legislation, the Commonwealth would act accordingly.

Where were the Queensland Aboriginal communities 18 months ago? Where are they now? An honourable senator might say that, in an ideal world, he would like the situation to be otherwise. But I put it to him, as I put it to all honourable senators and to all Australians, that the Commonwealth has given a serious undertaking, that there has been enormous progress and that the reserve residents of Queensland can now look forward to things which they could not have envisaged 18 months ago. We are bound by that guarantee. We shall act upon it if the need arises. But we will work now, as we are working and have worked, to promote circumstances in which the guarantee will not be used. We will be working to see that the new Act is applied generously; to see that it is applied constructively, to see that it is applied in line with the principles laid down by the Queensland Government; and to see that it is applied to the benefit of the Aboriginal communities and the Aboriginal people. The grant of deeds in trust will give a sound base to the communities on which they can build their futures. They can pursue their ideas for self-management-I might say that the self-management part of the package is yet to emerge-and they can enjoy a large measure of local discretion; all of the things promised by the Queensland Government in its public statements.

I have tried to draw a picture of progress month by month. We have moved from one situation which looked negative and desperate to a situation today where we see some real achievement. I do not believe that the situation ends there. The whole history of Aboriginal land tenure in this country has been one of movement . Aboriginal people held about one per cent of the land area of Australia 10 years ago and they now hold 9.6 per cent. This change has occurred in 10 years and will continue to occur. The situation today is not the situation we might have in two years or three years. We will be watching, trying to see what emerges in the light of experience. But we have a developing situation. I ask the Senate to acknowledge that it is a dynamic situation and not static.

Other companion Queensland legislation is still to be prepared. We are involved in negotiations on this. We shall watch this further legislation very closely. We shall watch the fine print of the grant of deeds in trust. We will ensure that for the reserve communities the fine print is in accord with what we have promised. The guarantee which I have mentioned applies just as much to the fine print of these grants as it does to the emergence of new legislation and legislation already passed. We would welcome honourable senators opposite- Senator Ryan in particular-joining with us in constructive efforts to advance the interests of Aboriginal and Islander people in Queensland, especially those living on reserves.

Let us come back to Senator Ryan's Aboriginal Land Rights Legislation Amendment Bill. It seems that all Senator Ryan can talk about is her Bill-her one constructive effort over the last 18 months. It is still an ineffective Bill. It still represents an imposed arrangement. It still has internal inconsistencies because of its drafting. It still remains premature. I come back to the point that I do not believe that it will advantage the Aboriginal communities because of its consequences in terms of matters which Queensland has to administer. We have made an unequivocal guarantee. We stand ready to act upon it.

Senator Ryan had a few words to say about the Commonwealth Games during her speech. I remind her that she is not helping the public debate in this country by issuing a Press release saying to Aboriginal people that they have two courses of action open to them: The first course is to try to persuade the Government to pass her Bill and the second course-I quote from her Press release -is that they can 'put all their energies into organising protests at the Commonwealth Games'. I think Australia deserves better than to have a spokesperson for the Australian Labor Party advising Aboriginals to put all their efforts into organising protests at the Commonwealth Games. These Games are for all Australians. It is not suitable for the Australian Labor Party or its representative in this place to be urging Aboriginals to mount protests with all their effort.

I wonder how many more times I will need to explain to honourable senators that there has been no failure on the part of the Commonwealth to secure appropriate rights for Aboriginal people in Queensland. How many more times will we have to remind honourable senators of what we have done? I remind honourable senators that the Queensland Government has acknowledged that it will issue titles to Aboriginal communities where no titles existed; that these titles will be forever, they will be titles without end; that they cannot be revoked without the Parliament reviewing that revocation; that they will be controlled by community councils; and that the Commonwealth has guaranteed that the Queensland Government's intention to deal honourably with its communities will be met and will not fail. I believe that the matter of public importance before us has no merit. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the fifth report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts I present the one hundred and ninety-eighth report of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The one hundred and ninety-eighth report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts is the result of the Committee's investigation into the administration and management of the Government Aircraft Factories at Fishermens Bend and Avalon. I must stress that while the Committee' s investigations relate largely to those Government Aircraft Factories a great deal of the report has relevance to all government factories. Many of the problems we identified, in particular the problems for a commercially oriented organisation operating within a government framework, may be applicable to other areas of government commercial activity.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the early 1970s the GAF received repeated criticism from the Auditor- General with regard to its accounting, financial control and management procedures. The Auditor-General's unfavourable comments in his reports for 1979- 80 and previous years led the Committee to the conclusion that the problems being experienced at the GAF, whilst serious breaches of Commonwealth accounting practice and procedure, were a symptom of more complex issues, including the management of the factories and their relationships with the mainstream departmental administration in Canberra.

The Committee's investigation of the GAF concentrated on these three main areas : Firstly, issues raised by the Auditor-General; secondly, efficiency of the factories' management, including level of support received from the Department of Industry and Commerce in Canberra; and thirdly, the future of the maintenance of production capability appropriation and the current and future viability of the aircraft industry which was referred to in great detail in the 1976 report of the Industries Assistance Commission.

In our examination of the comments of the Auditor-General in relation to specific matters of accounting procedure and practice we found a low standard of government accounting resulting from years of neglect. Consequently, we endorse the comments of the Auditor-General when he says that:
. . . collectively the unsatisfactory accounting disclosed by audit represented a critical state of affairs.

The Committee cannot excuse the GAF's neglect of many basic accounting procedures and practices. Nor can it excuse the lack of action by management at the GAF to rectify these irregularities, particularly since many have been the subject of repeated comments by the Auditor-General over the last decade.

The Committee is in no doubt that there has been a lack of commitment by senior management at the GAF and the Department of Industry and Commerce to the observations of the Auditor-General and a regrettable tardiness in the control of existing systems and implementation of new systems to take account of the changing requirements of modern business practice. Management at the Government Aircraft Factories has consistently proven over the last decade its inability to react to constructive criticism directed at encouraging remedial action or even to rectify problems of this nature that it has identified. An example of this was 'project phoenix', a management review which cost the taxpayers $1m between 1973 and 1976 in consultants and equipment costs. It appears to have had little effect on managerial efficiencies. The Committee found that management of the Government Aircraft Factories had only a rudimentary knowledge of this review. As 'project phoenix' was originally designed to produce a continuous system of managerial review designed to produce savings of around $1m per annum, the Committee regards the handling of this project as quite unacceptable.

We examined in some detail management deficiencies at the factories and found that in the areas of staffing, working conditions, remuneration, industrial relations and the adoption of modern business practices, the Government Aircraft Factories lagged far behind their competitors in private industry. The Committee feels that the multitude of problems facing the Government Aircraft Factories is due to the lack of a co-ordinated and integrated approach to its responsibilities by factory management over the last decade and a lack of prompt action on factory issues by the Department here in Canberra. The Public Accounts Committee believes that the major reason why the Government Aircraft Factories have been unable to develop adequate management and financial control systems is the extraordinarily long decision making process involving the General Manager of the GAF, the Department of Industry and Commerce in Canberra and the various other departments such as Defence, Finance, Administrative Services, the Public Service Board and so on, all of which have an input into many areas of the factory management. This process severely limits the General Manager's ability to respond in a timely and effective fashion to day to day management problems and to develop modern management practices. The Committee strongly endorses the general proposition of 'letting the managers manage'. The inflexibility and inefficiency caused by the present management approach should be eliminated.

A further area of concern to the Committee is the fluctuating work load in the aircraft industry as a result of the time-lag between major defence re-equipment programs. Because of this the industry suffers in morale and retention of technological research and manufacturing capability. The Committee is of the view that if the GAF is to function efficiently in a quasi-competitive environment then many of the problems caused by its formal attachment to the mainstream of government departmental administration must be removed. Possible options canvassed by the Committee included: GAF and other government factories being formed into separate, independent statutory corporations with policy advice and co-ordination being provided through a new department of defence production; a tripartite aerospace corporation including the Commonwealth Aircraft Corporation Ltd, Hawker De Havilland Australia Pty Ltd and the Government Aircraft Factories with the Commonwealth retaining a proportionate share of the equity; and a separate company to include GAF with a majority shareholding vested in the Commonwealth. The Committee concluded that the most acceptable solution would be the first: Re-form the Government Aircraft Factories into a statutory corporation. This solution could also be applied to all other government defence factories.

Our conclusions and recommendations are directed towards placing the Government Aircraft Factories on a more efficient commercial footing. However, irrespective of GAF's future, the Committee recommends that financial reporting arrangements for the GAF be rationalised taking account of the many new developments in government accounting practice currently under consideration by the Government and this Committee. In this regard, the Committee will shortly table a report on the form and standard of financial statements of Commonwealth undertakings. This must include one set of accounts prepared and submitted to the production board as statements examined by the Auditor-General which are then presented to the Parliament as a record of the financial achievements of GAF. The major point, however, to emerge from the inquiry was the inappropriate nature of a government departmental framework for the efficient operation of commercial undertakings. It is essential to remove the Government Aircraft Factories from this framework and place such undertakings on a similar footing to private industry, particularly regarding decision making processes. It is also considered important to centralise the policy and co-ordination function for the operation of government factories into one separate department reporting directly to an appropriate Minister. I commend the report to honourable senators.

I was enormously impressed by the report as presented by Senator Watson. I think it is a great shame that so few senators were present to hear and understand his speech. SPEECH.PARA: It passes my comprehension how that sort of criticism expressed over the years can be treated with utter and total contempt by permanent heads and, indeed, by Ministers involved in this matter. The nightmarish situation described by Senator Watson is that five departments-I lost count after five-have an input into factory management before really hard decisions can be made. Although Senator Watson had some harsh things to say about the management of the Government Aircraft Factories I believe that underlying those criticisms there was a note of sympathy in his and the Committee's consideration and a feeling that they were trying to fight a losing battle with one or both hands tied behind their backs by utterly confounded, confused bureaucracy. One wonders where these things finish. I know that members of committees, like those on which Senator Watson so ably serves, sometimes wonder whether-Senator Rae would be another person who has contributed magnificently to the committee system of this Parliament-the Government takes enough note of the hours of valuable work put in by these committees when they come down with decisions, conclusions and recommendations in the way Senator Watson presented them today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there are many old PAC people in the Government.

—I thank the honourable senator for that interjection. Perhaps that very fact should increase the criticism that can be levelled at members of the Government and members of the Cabinet that having served that apprenticeship , an extraordinarily valuable report such as has just been presented by Senator Watson can have virtually no action taken on it. I serve notice in the Senate that, as a compliment to Senator Watson and his colleagues for the work that they have done on this Committee, the Australian Democrats, at least, will be watching very carefully for a Government response on this report. After giving the Government a reasonable amount of time in which to make a response and to react in some way we will be raising the matter in the Senate constantly until this massive waste of taxpayers' funds is remedied and some form of efficiency is restored to this very important defence area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill amends the Social Services Act with respect to the payment of family allowance to certain temporary residents of Australia, the waiting periods of unemployment and sickness benefit and the recovery of sickness benefit from compensation payments. It also contains a number of minor technical and machinery amendments.

As honourable senators are aware, family allowance is payable to parents residing in Australia who have the custody, care and control of children under the age of 16 or who have dependent full-time student children aged between 16 and 25. In the case of parents not born in Australia, and where there is no clear intention to reside here permanently, family allowance is payable after residence in Australia for 12 months. Under these provisions, family allowance is payable to diplomats and consuls and their non-locally-engaged staff, and to overseas armed forces personnel who are not attached to the Australian forces, and to the close families of these persons. Such persons have no real claim on the Australian community for the support of their children. Rather, they are the responsibility of their own governments. It was never envisaged that the family allowance scheme should encompass the support of people in these circumstances and it is considered appropriate that the eligibility which these people have at present should be removed.
Similarly, as the law stands at present, family allowance is payable with respect to the children of a person who is a prohibited immigrant and has entered or remained in Australia without approval.
The Bill renders such persons ineligible to receive family allowance.

If, of course, the position of a prohibited immigrant is regularised under the provisions of the Migration Act, thus rendering him eligible to remain in Australia, his exclusion from family allowance would cease.

As regards diplomatic personnel, I mention that there are situations in which certain countries are represented by honourary consuls who are Australian citizens or permanent residents. The amendment in the Bill will not apply to such persons as the exclusion is expressly limited to persons in the relevant categories who are not Australian citizens or permanent residents.
I turn now to the provisions in the Bill which will modify the operation of the rules which specify the day from which unemployment and sickness benefit is payable.

New administrative arrangements were made last year under which claims for unemployment benefit are lodged with the Department of Social Security rather than the Commonwealth Employment Service as was previously the case. Unemployment benefit is payable from 7 days after the date the person became unemployed, or 7 days after the date he makes a claim, whichever is the later. It has become apparent that in some circumstances, an unavoidable delay occurs between the time an unemployed person registers as unemployed with the Commonwealth Employment Service and obtains a claim form for unemployment benefit, and the time that the claim is lodged with the Department of Social Security. Where for instance, people in rural areas receive and submit claims by post, the lodging of this form with the Department of Social Security may be delayed. As a result, entitlement to unemployment benefit is delayed.

The Bill provides that, where a person registers as unemployed with the Commonwealth Employment Service, and his claim for unemployment benefit is made within 14 days of the date of that registration, he will be regarded as having made a claim on the day on which he registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service. In special cases, such as where mails or travel are disrupted by floods , bush fires, industrial disputes etc, the Director-General will be able to extend the period of 14 days, thus further minimising any adverse effect of the claim being delayed.

The Bill also amends the provisions of the Social Services Act relating to the waiting period for sickness benefit. Generally, under the exisiting provisions a claimant for sickness benefit is required to serve a 7-day waiting period before entitlement to benefit commences provided he has not already served such a waiting period in the previous 13 weeks. There are people who suffer chronic illnesses who require treatment or who otherwise become incapacitated for work in respect of the same sickness at periods longer than 13 weeks. In these cases a claimant is required to serve a second waiting period on recurrence of the incapacity. This can cause hardship where such people have exhausted their sick leave entitlements and have no other means of support during the waiting period. The Bill rectifies this situation by providing that the waiting period may be waived in respect of a recurring incapacity which is connected with the cause of a previous incapacity in respect of which sickness benefit was paid.

The Bill also amends the provisions of Division 3A of Part VII of the Act. These provisions were enacted in 1979 but have not been proclaimed because of a number of administrative and machinery deficiencies.

The principles embodied in Division 3A extend the principles already contained in section 115 of the Social Services Act and are not new. Section 115 provides that, if compensation is received for the same incapacity as that which qualifies a person for sickness benefit, and it is paid for the same period in respect of which he is qualified to receive sickness benefit, then the rate of the benefit normally payable for that period is reduced by the amount of the relevant part of the compensation. Similarly, sickness benefit may be recovered where the compensation is subsequently paid for the same period for which sickness benefit has been paid. Typically, this occurs where a person receives sickness benefit whilst awaiting settlement of a compensation claim, and some or all of the sickness benefit paid, is recovered on settlement. These provisions ensure that a person does not receive a 'double payment' in respect of an incapacity for work and that responsibility for maintaining the incapacitated worker is properly borne by the third party liable to pay compensation, rather than the community.

Section 115 does have a number of shortcomings and these shortcomings have been exploited to circumvent the recovery provisions to which I have made reference. It was in order to address these problems that Division 3A was enacted in 1979 to strengthen and clarify that provision where necessary.

Division 3A has itself been found to have a number of deficiencies. It was because of a concern that the Division would not be as effective as intended that there has been delay in bringing its provisions into operation.

For example, Division 3A as drafted would not encompass compensation payable under no-fault motor accident schemes because its terms are restricted to cases where compensation arises by reason of a judgment of a court or an agreement in settlement of a claim. The amendments will remove this restriction.

The existing Division 3A also makes for cumbersome administration in some respects. The provisions under which notices relating to recovery of sickness benefit are given to the parties involved require the same notices to be given to both an insurer and a third party. Experience has shown that third parties who are insured do not wish to become involved in these matters, and the amendments provide that it is necessary to give notices only to the insurer. This will reflect the position at present under section 115, and avoid both costs to third parties and in administration.

The amendments also enable notices to be given more efficiently, so that a more effective service is provided to insurers subject to the legislation. At present , notices under Division 3A would have to be given only by post. The amendments will enable the Director-General to give a notice to an insurer over the counter , in appropriate circumstances. This will also reflect the current position under section 115.

A further amendment changes the way in which the Director-General directs that compensation is to be taken into account in these situations. The existing Division 3A requires the Director-General to give a direction as to the rate of sickness benefit to be paid. This is cumbersome, because the rate of sickness benefit may alter for other reasons, such as a receipt of income, and a new direction would be necessary. The amendments require the Director-General to give a direction as to the amount by which sickness benefit is to be reduced in taking account of compensation. If the rate of sickness benefit alters for other reasons, it will not be necessary to make a new direction.
Other amendments remove a number of other deficiencies in Division 3A of a machinery nature.
As I have said, the Bill also contains machinery or administrative changes to other parts of the Act, as well as a substantial number of minor or formal amendments of a drafting nature.

Prior to 1972, the Department of Social Security was known as the Department of Social Services. The Social Services Act has not been amended to reflect this change of name. The Bill therefore proposes to change the title of the Act to the Social Security Act and the title of the Director-General of Social Services to the Director-General of Social Security. References to other specific offices within the Department will also be similarly amended.

The Government's initiative in 1976 in introducing a new system of family allowances is not fully reflected in the terminology of the Act. The Bill replaces a number of out-dated references to 'child endowment' with references to 'family allowance'.
The Bill also incorporates an amendment to clarify the entitlement of institutions to family allowance in respect of dependent full-time students between the ages of 16 and 25.

Another amendment will extend the notification provisions of the Act with respect to handicapped child's allowance, where the child has left the home in which he or she was receiving constant care and attention. This will ensure that the person with continuing entitlement to allowance is identified at an early stage.
A schedule to the Bill proposes amendments which will remove some technical inconsistencies in the legislation and bring the legislative drafting style into line with current practice.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
