TALK.START.PARA: —The Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1982 is an omnibus Bill containing some 10 significant amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act. The amendments include alterations to zone allowances and to depreciation rates for machinery used in steel production. The Bill contains provisions which attempt to thwart the bizarre decisions handed down by the High Court of Australia which have emasculated vital provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act, in particular the existing section 136. The replacement of section 136, together with major amendments to section 26AAA are- I think the Treasurer (Mr Howard) explicitly agreed with this- the major amendments contained in this Bill. Section 136 is concerned with international tax avoidance through transfer pricing arrangements. Section 26AAA is concerned with domestic tax avoidance through the conversion of what ought to be regarded as income into capital gain and to do so in a way which is tax free.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition will be moving both an amendment to the motion for the second reading and a number of amendments in the Committee stage of this Bill. I have just been informed that copies of those amendments are currently being prepared and will be circulated. The amendments to section 26AAA-that section of the Act which is designed, to limited extent, to prevent the conversion of income tax free capital gain-have been prompted by three spectacular recent cases of tax avoidance through the use or misuse of that section. Two of these cases involved Mr Holmes a Court and the other involved the Bond Corporation. A total revenue loss of in the vicinity of $27m resulted from those three examples alone. Not surprisingly, several of the amendments which will be moved in the Committe stage are directed at recovering for the public revenue the tax so far evaded. The Government has for many years been involved in a circular exercise with respect to taxation. It has attempted to close loopholes in the Act, many of which were inserted by its own silly pork barrelling amendments of the recent past. It has also attempted to deal with the assortment of bizarre interpretations of the Income Tax Assessment Act handed down by the High Court of Australia.

The Government has two types of problems in the area of taxation. The first is its cynical misuse of the Income Tax Assessment Act for pork barrelling purposes . Recent examples, one of which this Bill sets out to correct, concerned the provisions relating to tax deductions for works of art donated to public institutions. A couple of years ago other amendments were required to clean up the pork barrelling rort which the Government had deliberately written into the Act concerning film production. Since cleaning up the last but one film production rort, cynically and deliberately written into the Act, the Government has inserted another film production rort which, in its time, I forecast will also be the subject of legislation before the Senate, aimed at cleaning it up.

Other examples of rorts deliberately inserted by this Government include the income equalisation deposit provisions under which it is possible for any person with a high off-farm income and substantial farming interests to lend $10,000 for one year, borrow $15,000 for each of two years-that is, borrow three times as much as he lends-and pick up a cash bonus of $4,609, half of which is free from tax. Over generous tax averaging provisions, according to a question asked originally by my colleague, Ralph Willis, and answered in February, cost the revenue $215m in the last taxation year. The Government has consistently inserted rorts of that type into the Act and has then been faced with the problem of attempting to clean them up. This legislation falls partially into that category. To the extent that the Government's problems in that area are of its own making, an appropriate response is 'Serve it right'.

The second problem which the Government has is caused by the parasitic tax dodging industry which has been aided and abetted by the High Court, particularly during the period when it was under the tutelage of Sir Garfield Barwick. Barwick himself is, of course, a tax evader. He lived in a house owned by Mundroola Pty Ltd, a company of which he was a director, without declaring in his taxation returns any imputed rent as he was obliged to do under the Act. It is not surprising that a Chief Justice who was himself a tax evader should take a sympathetic view of tax evasion by others. When the Mundroola scandal broke early in 1980 there hastily appeared a letter hastily in which the Chief Justice resigned his directorship. It was dated April 1974. The ink was still wet.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I draw your attention to Standing Order 418 and perhaps Standing Order 419. I believe Senator Walsh is reflecting upon the integrity of a former member of this Parliament. In respect of Standing Order 419 he is digressing greatly from the subject matter before the Chair.
—No protection is given to former members of this House under Standing Order 418. There is no point of order. I call Senator Walsh.

—The public record clearly shows-it is relevant to the subject matter of this Bill-that many of the problems and a great deal of the tax evasion which has corrupted this country are attributable to the former Chief Justice and his influence on the Bench. The public record shows him to be not only an accessory to and practitioner of tax evasion but also a falsifier of company documents. I do not know of anyone in this Parliament who believes that the letter dated 1974, which surfaced in 1980, in which Barwick resigned his directorship of Mundroola was written in 1974. I do not know of anyone in this Parliament who believes that that letter was not written in 1980.

—Senator Walsh, it was mentioned earlier that you may have been digressing from the Bill that is under discussion. I have taken a wide view of the comments that you have made but I think that you are now digressing. I ask you to speak to the Bill that is before the Senate.

—Very well, Mr Acting Deputy President, I shall comply with your wishes. The Government, as it has shown by the way in which it has opened up loopholes in the Act, has no great moral objection to tax avoidance. At least 40 concessions, including the couple to which I have already referred, have been inserted into the Act during the lifetime of this Government. But it has been compelled to act to some extent regardless of any moral reservations which it may have had, but apparently has not, when the leakage of revenue due to tax avoidance and evasion became so high that it could no longer be ignored. Much of the legislation that we have seen in the last three or four years is aimed at closing the loopholes found in earlier anti-tax avoidance legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: In spite of the Government's continuing failure to close off this damaging leakage of public revenue, it refuses to take the one relatively simple action which would solve the problem. It refuses to legislate retrospectively against tax avoidance. Because of its refusal to do so and because of its penchant for deliberately inserting loopholes into the Act at the behest of favoured clients, since 1976 the Income Tax Assessment Act has grown from 700 pages to 976 pages, not including the index or the notes, and as a result of this Bill it will increase by another 39 pages. The very complexity and length of the Act facilitate evasion. It is so cumbersome as to be almost incomprehensible. It will get worse unless the Government grasps the nettle as the Labor Party has for years urged it to do and declares a firm intention to legislate retrospectively against tax avoidance.

We will give the Government the opportunity to declare an intention to do that when the Committee stage of this Bill is reached. The amendments to clause 4 of the amending Bill, which I notice have just been circulated, will then be moved. That clause amends the existing section 26AAA of the Act. That section was the device used by the Bond Corporation and by Mr Holmes a Court's Bell group to collect some $60m in tax free profit. On behalf of the Opposition I move the amendment to the motion for the second reading which has just been circulated in my name. I move:
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that it is deficient in that:

(a) penalties contained in the Bill for participation in transfer pricing type tax avoidance arrangements are insufficient to provide suitable deterrents against tax avoidance and are inconsistent with penalties contained elsewhere in the Act;

(b) without the accompanying adoption of a code of conduct for transnational corporations, as recommended by the OECD and the United Nations, the effectiveness of Division 13 is likely to be limited by the difficulty confronting the Taxation Commissioner in obtaining adequate information;
(c) the Bill fails to take retrospective action against persons flouting the tax system through the blatant avoidance schemes utilising section 26AAA of the Act; and
(d) the Bill endorses use by the medical profession of corporate and trust arrangements with significant tax avoidance implications'.

Although we have given the Government the opportunity to legislate effectively against tax avoidance, we are realists enough to know that the Government will not accept that opportunity. We do, however, hope that the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine show some commitment to smashing tax evasion, a commitment which the Labor Party has firmly had for many years. When these amendments are moved in the Committee stage, the opportunity will be presented to the Democrats and to Senator Harradine to show that they, too, are opposed to tax avoidance and that they will take effective action to stop it. If they decline that opportunity they will join the ranks of those who support tax dodgers. Let us be perfectly clear about this. Failure to vote for the amendments to clause 4 of this Bill will signify support for tax dodgers. Not only will it signify support for tax dodgers; but it will be a practical expression of support for tax dodgers, a licence for them to continue their anti-social activity. Those people have already been responsible, to a substantial degree, for the 80 per cent increase in the level of tax paid by single income families with two children on an income of 85 per cent of average weekly earnings. This is almost the stereotype of the family which this Government purports to be concerned about and which, I expect, Senator Harradine would claim also to be deeply concerned about.

There has been an 80 per cent increase in the rate of taxation applying to families in that category since 1975. They are paying the penalty for tax evasion. Unless Senator Harradine and the Democrats have the wit and courage to join with the Labor Party in supporting those amendments, tax dodging will continue and families in that category and in other categories will continue to pay the penalty for it. Those who fail to support these amendments will be endorsing also the 22 per cent aggregate increase on taxation of pay-as-you-earn taxpayers this financial year. That is a 22 per cent increase, according to the Budget Estimates, in taxation paid by wage and salary earners. Again, to a substantial extent, that enormous increase is attributable to the continuing existence of tax evasion and tax avoidance.

Tax evasion has developed into a cancer. It has contributed to a very serious moral decline in the community. I often wish that those people who are obsessed with prying into bedrooms and other like activities, such as the Reverend Nile, for example, would show a bit more concern about this type of moral decadence which has infected large sections of the community. Indeed, it appears to have infected probably most of the self-employed who have followed the example set by the Government and its favoured clients and have taken all possible steps to evade and avoid the greatest possible amount of taxation to the cost of every other member of the community.

One of the favoured clients to which I referred is the hierarchy or the elite of the National Farmers Federation. The Federation was reported this morning as urging metal workers not to accept the $14 a week pay increase which they have been granted, effective from, I think, the middle of June. On the grounds of social responsibility, metal workers were urged to forgo that pay increase. This has been urged by the National Farmers Federation, a favoured client of this Government. I find it almost unbelievable and incomprehensible that the National Farmers Federation, which is simultaneously attempting to raid the Treasury to the extent of securing an effective interest rate of 32.5 per cent on deposits in a government trust account, expects to be taken seriously when it urges metal workers on $220 a week to forgo a $14 a week wage rise already granted to them. I might add that the metal workers pay a hell of a lot more tax than they would have paid six years ago for a comparable level of income. Likewise, of course, this Government, which has opened up the loopholes which make that sort of raid on the public purse possible, has no moral authority to deal with the metal workers or with anyone else.

I daresay that we will hear one or both of two lines of defence from the Government members. The first will be that the Government has taken effective action against tax avoidance and tax evasion. Supplementary to that, if precedent is any guide, we will be told that the Labor Party was pretty dreadful because it did not do something about tax avoidance when it was in government. My first response is that even if the Labor Party was guilty as charged, that does not excuse the inertia and the culpable negligence of this Government. I concede that there were areas of tax avoidance that the Labor Government should have acted against and it failed to do so. There were many other areas where it did act against tax avoidance and evasion. Of course, in 1973 or 1975 the problem had not reached the scale that it has reached now. It is impossible to put precise figures on this, but the amount of revenues lost through tax avoidance is probably 10 times as great now as it was when Labor was in government.

The second defence which may be offered by Government members will probably centre on some spurious argument that all incentive is removed if the taxation system is too efficient. I hope we do not hear that argument, but I fear that we might. In the past we have heard from Senator Bjelke-Petersen, and even from some people who ought to know better, that if the maximum marginal tax rate was not so high there would not be so much tax avoidance and evasion. The maximum marginal tax rate is lower now than it has been at any time since uniform taxation was introduced in 1942. As the maximum marginal rate came down, tax avoidance went up. That is an empirical fact. It does not necessarily prove that one caused the other but it does establish that reducing the maximum marginal rate of tax is not an effective way of stopping tax avoidance. Nor would the very much larger reduction in the marginal rate that would be made possible if all income were uniformly taxed eliminate tax avoidance and evasion.

People who say that they believe that are asking us to believe that these people who have successfully devised ways of evading their social responsibilities by avoiding taxation will, because the maximum marginal rate has been reduced from 60c to 35c-which is about the magnitude of the change which is feasible-suddenly become socially responsible philanthropists who will no longer indulge in tax evasion and tax avoidance even though they have perfected formulas for doing so. Even before the moral decadence which has been induced by continuing widespread tax evasion set in in this society, I do not believe that there was such a strong sense of moral responsibility that the rich , who have shown such a desire to evade tax, would suddenly have developed a social conscience and a sense of social responsibility.

The way to stop tax avoidance is to issue a credible threat of retrospective legislation. The opportunity to make this legislation effectively retrospective will arise in the Committee stage when I will move the first group of Committee amendments which have been circulated in my name. For the record, the second group of amendments seeks to increase the penalties which will be applied for breaches of the proposed new Division 13; that is, the transfer pricing section of the Act. The amendments which I will later move seek to increase the penalties applicable for breaches of that proposed new Division to the level established in section 226 of the Act for similar breaches of other sections of the Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1982. I want to speak to that section which is intended to vary the zone allowance system and to increase the zone rebate in some instances. The thrust of the proposals which are to be effective from 1 November 1981 is to increase the zone rebate that is related to dependants and to provide a special basic rebate of $750 in lieu of the ordinary basic zone A and zone B rebates for people residing or spending the required period of time at places in excess of 250 kilometres, by the shortest practical surface route, from the centre of the nearest population centre of 2,500 people or more.

SPEECH.PARA: The existing eligibility for a zone rebate under which a person must reside or actually be in a zone for more than half the year of income will be liberalised. Firstly, a person who resides or spends time in a zone area for 183 days or more over a period of two consecutive income years but who does not satisfy the existing test in relation to either income year is to receive a rebate in the latter income year. Secondly, a person who resides in a zone area for a continuous period of up to five income years but who does not satisfy the existing test in the first and last of those income years will be entitled to a rebate in the last year provided the period in the first income year combined with that in the last income year exceeds 183 days. The dependant rebate will rise from 25 per cent to 50 per cent of the relevant dependant rebate amounts for zone A and from 4 per cent to 20 per cent for zone B.

I commend the Government for this action so far as it goes. However, I consider the increase to be far too small if it is to fulfil the purpose for which it is intended. Zone tax allowances were introduced in 1945-46 at a rate of $80 for a person in zone A and $40 for a resident in zone B. By 1958 the allowance had increased to $540 in zone A plus one half of the total deductions for dependants . Over the 13 years from 1945 to 1958 when inflation was not a significant factor, mindful of the purpose of the allowance, it was increased to more than 10 times the original allowance. Over the ensuing 22 years from 1958 to 1980 the dollar value of the allowance was not increased for a single person and was increased by only $168 for a married taxpayer with a dependant spouse and two children. In fact due to the allowance being transferred from a deduction to a rebate its value has, for many people materially declined. The increases outlined in this Bill are, by any standards, inadequate and clearly are not made on the basis on which the allowance was first made in 1945. There has been a significant decline in the value of the zone allowance over the past 20 years. It has been calculated that in 1947-48 a medium taxpayer in zone A with a wife and two children obtained a 66 per cent reduction in tax liability through a zonal tax concession scheme. However, by 1977-78 this relative degree of tax reduction had declined to about 20 per cent.

The Western Australian Government's submission to the public inquiry on income tax zone allowances demonstrates, from the Commissioner of Taxation's fifty- eighth report of 1978-79, that the average tax collected from taxpayers residing in zone A and zone B in 1977-78 and having assessable incomes was $2,062 per taxpayer allowing for the zone rebate. Taxpayers outside zone A and zone B paid an average of $1,894 per taxpayer-$167 less. This represents an extra $37,313, 098 in tax paid by taxpayers in zone areas while the value of the rebates in the same year was $28,356,000. The taxpayers in these areas actually contributed an additional $9m in taxation receipts, contrary to what is regarded as the intention of the Government to compensate these persons for the higher costs and disabilities experienced in these areas.

It is appropriate to gauge the measure of assistance provided by the reduction in taxation produced by the zone allowance as a percentage of income or, more realistically, as a percentage of disposable income or income less tax. Considering the period from 1958-59 to 1979-80 for a single person, the percentage of zone allowance to average weekly earnings has fallen from 4.8 per cent to 1.7 per cent in zone A and from 0.9 per cent to 0.3 per cent in zone B. If a family of a taxpayer, a spouse and two children is considered, the percentage of zone allowance to average weekly earnings has fallen from 4.6 per cent to 3.8 per cent in zone A or from 1.5 per cent to 0.6 per cent in zone B over the same period.

If the average weekly earnings after tax are considered for a family of a taxpayer, a spouse and two children, the reduction has been from 6.3 per cent to 4.7 per cent in zone A and from 1.6 per cent to 0.8 per cent in zone B. It can be seen that in both zone A and zone B over the period from 1958-59 to 1979-80 effectively the zone allowance for the married wage earner with three dependents who was earning the average weekly wage was reduced by between 25 per cent and 50 per cent, and for a single wage earner it was reduced by 50 per cent. Of course to compensate for the high cost of living and other considerations, wage earners in the zone areas have to earn far in excess of the average weekly wage and so the percentage drop to many of these people is much greater than a calculation based on an average wage, and due to the allowance now being a rebate and not a deduction from assessable income, as I mentioned earlier, these people are further penalised.

It ought to be remembered that not all employers within the zone areas are able to pay high levels of wages required to attract a capable and stable work force. Added to this cost burden, these businessmen are faced with higher costs for freight, communications, maintenance and building costs, air conditioning and stock on hand and, to attract good labour, are often required to provide housing for the employees. Not only is this a responsibility that their metropolitan competitors do not have to carry, but also the cost of housing in isolated parts of Australia, and particularly Western Australia, is very high. Many of the small businesses in the North West of Western Australia are in the service industries which are invariably labour intensive.

The higher wages required to attract labour to these areas cause a flow-on of high living costs which in themselves drive wages up into a higher tax bracket. Similar difficulties occur in the pastoral industry which competes in the world markets and has absolutely no insulation against these high wage demands. More than any other sector of industry which is located and required to operate in isolated areas, the pastoral industry is most adversely affected by high wage demands and other associated costs, such as freight, communications, spare parts and food costs.

In its submission to the public inquiry on zone allowances, the Western Australian Government clearly illustrated this point. It noted that in the town of Kununurra over the two-year period 1978-79 and 1979-80 food prices were an average of 36.5 per cent higher than in Perth. While it is accepted that Kununurra may well be an extreme example, it nevertheless remains that country towns in Western Australia fall somewhere in this range. Likewise, considering another necessity-housing-the State Housing Commission of Western Australia estimated that the cost of building a three bedroom house in Port Hedland, suitable for Pilbara conditions, was 78 per cent higher than in Perth. That cost differential does not include an additional $3,000 which the commission also estimated was necessary in order to provide a wide verandah for cooling purposes . Honourable senators will agree, I am sure, that that is a necessity in the northern parts of Australia.

Moreover, given the extreme isolation of many parts of Australia, especially in Western Australia, it is not unreasonable for people to need to fly to their capital city at least once a year. For a family of four based at Halls Creek, for example, that could mean expenditure in the range of $2,700. Once again this is not a cost to which those in the less remote, more temperate climates are exposed. Even if these trips are regarded as a luxury by some of my colleagues, I doubt whether anyone can deny that with the requirements of children's education or specialist medical attention some transport costs will necessarily be incurred, while people in the major cities simply never encounter these problems. Even if those in our more remote, northern areas decide to stay at home, there is always the aspect of air conditioning which I am sure all honourable senators will agree is a necessity in those parts. Air conditioning costs could double electricity consumption and involve households in these areas with power costs as much as $540 higher than those in more temperate climates.

When we consider the size of zone allowances we ought to bear in mind their purpose and ask whether the level of these rebates is likely to fulfil the purpose for which they are provided. It appears reasonable therefore to suggest that the rationale for zonal tax concessions rests on two grounds. The first is the national political and economic objective of seeking decentralisation of population and industry away from the centralised metropolitan areas of the States, an object which can be stated as requiring the development of all the resources of the Commonwealth irrespective of their location. Where that location is bad with respect to markets or other inputs, concessions may be required to ensure that those resources are developed. Decentralisation concessions to industry are accepted by the Commonwealth Government and by some State Governments. The zonal tax concessions are a component of these more general decentralisation concessions which benefit workers rather than employers .

The second rationale for zonal tax concessions is related to the social philosophy of taxation rather than to mere political and economic principles. This second rationale refers to the principle of horizontal equity in the distribution of the tax burden, the attainment of which requires that persons in equal circumstances should pay the same tax. The problem of course has always been in determining equal circumstances. It has generally been agreed that to compute equal circumstances allowance should be made for such things as expenditure incurred in earning assessable income, expenditure on social services such as health and education, and the number of dependants supported by the taxpayer. To this list zonal tax concessions add a further reason, namely, that the costs referred to above may vary among locations in a way for which the existing tax system does not compensate. Thus the wage or salary earner may be paid an additional income based on location to offset, say, high living costs, but this additional income is fully taxable and therefore the high living costs are not offset.

This second rationale can be given a more precise definition if 'equal circumstances' is taken to mean the real value of income, not the money value of income. The present taxation system taxes money income. Taxation based on the real value of income would take account of the purchasing value of income at the location of the residence of the taxpayer. With such an approach money incomes in high cost of living locations would be deflated or subject to a defined reduction to offset the high prices paid by residents in those locations.

Mr Acting Deputy President, the people who work in the remote areas are not provided with the same level of services, to which, in equity, it can be properly argued that they are justly entitled to receive through their taxes, as are their fellow Australians who live in the capital cities and the more populated southern areas of Australia. Many people in isolated and remote areas do not have adequate telephone, television, sewerage, bus, or rail services, the full range of education and health services, and a host of other services on which a very large proportion of the taxation receipts is expended. It can fairly be claimed that the zone allowances must be regarded in part as compensation to people living in remote areas for not having normal access to the range of services and facilities provided to and expected by the great bulk of Australian people.

The compelling reason which should be of concern to all Australians is to encourage decentralisation in a practical and tangible way and we should be seeking to ensure that our country's natural resources, which are often found in isolated parts of the country, are fully exploited so as to provide our country with the abundant wealth which is available to it both on and under the ground. By populating these areas we are also of course ensuring their safeguard for future generations of Australians. Let me refer to my own State of Western Australia. I remind the Senate that Western Australia comprises one-third of the continent, being considerably larger than the total area of New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania and both islands of New Zealand and has a coastline of 12,500 kilometres which is about the same distance as between Perth and London. The Perth metropolitan area is the only urban centre with a population of over 25, 000 people. There are only three centres with populations near to 20,000 people, all of which lie in the southern, more populated area of the State.

It is generally accepted that a reasonable but still limited range of services can be provided in an urban centre of 25,000 people. Such services as specialist medical and para-medical treatment, tertiary education and some areas of technical education, a full range and sufficient choice of retail outlets and household services are not available until a much larger population is attained. Throughout Western Australia, the average distance of all urban centres and rural bounded localities with populations of 200 or more from the nearest urban centre of 25,000 people is 407 kilometres. This average distance is more than three times the comparable distance in other states and far greater than the distance in Tasmania which is only 69 kilometres. The existing income tax zone A covers 52 per cent of the area and has 6 per cent of the population of the State . Zone B covers 40 per cent of the area and has 5 per cent of the population of the State. Together both zones include 92 per cent of the area and 11 per cent of the population of Western Australia. In fact in all States both zone A and zone B together cover 78 per cent of the area and include 5 per cent of the population.

Therefore, the present taxation zone concessions apply only to a very small proportion of Australia's income earners who reside in an area of more than three quarters of the continent. The proportion of the nation's population living in the remote areas of the continent when these concessions were first provided in 1945 was 1.6 per cent in zone A and 4.3 per cent in zone B, or in total 5.9 per cent of the nation's population at that time. There has been a drop of 0.9 per cent in the population of these areas.

Therefore, in terms of population residing in zones A and B and that of Australia's near neighbours, and despite the enormous development of the mineral resources in zones A and B over the last decade, there is a far greater urgency to develop the remote areas now than there was in 1945. This 11 per cent of the population in Western Australia living in an area of over 92 per cent of the State produces over 40 per cent of the total primary production of the State of Western Australia, 40 per cent of the exports of the State and 8 per cent of Australia's exports.

As I move towards the conclusion of my comments I draw to the attention of the Senate the fact that the boundaries which were drawn in 1945 remain unchanged. Referring particularly to Western Australia, in 1945 the pastoral industry was by far the dominant industry north of the 26th parallel, which is normally considered to be the southern boundary of the north-west of Western Australia. The only other industries were the beef killing works at Wyndham and Broome, the pearling industry at Broome, an infant iron ore mining venture at Cockatoo Island and irrigated banana planations on the Gascoyne River. The Murchison and Eastern Goldfields depended entirely on the gold mining and pastoral industries. The northern and eastern wheat belts, the south-east and the Esperance- Ravensthorpe agricultural areas were not developed. The availability of transport and services in those areas in 1945 was very limited and the northern part of the State relied almost exclusively on coastal shipping.

With the more recent developments of the mining industry in the Pilbara, Kimberley and Goldfields, the Ord River project and the partial decline of the pastoral industry, the development that exists in zones A and B today bears little resemblance to that of 1945. Road transport has become the dominant means of transport for most of the remote areas with the exception of the remote wheat belt areas which are served by rail and road. The higher fuel prices that have occurred since the mid-1970s will continue to have a major influence on the cost of living in remote areas in this very large State of Western Australia. Because of the size of the State and the areas within zones A and B and the development that has taken place in the past 35 years, many serious anomalies are provided to residents in centres in both zone A and zone B. There is far too large a disparity in costs experienced in centres in zone A to provide a meaningful and equitable overall allowance. The same situation exists in zone B. The major influence on the relative costs is transport costs and the relative population of the centres which are reflected in the price structures in centres throughout the zones. For instance, within zone A road transport costs for general freight vary from 2.6 cents a kilogram from Perth to Carnarvon, a distance of 906 kilometres, to 16.5 cents a kilogram from Perth to Kununurra, a distance of 3, 184 kilometres and the shortest route; a variation of 800 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many kilometres was that?
—It is 3,184 kilometres by the most direct road.

SPEECH.PARA: The relative retail food price index prepared by the Australian Bureau of Statistics for Carnarvon and Kununurra vary from 108 to 135 respectively, with a base of 100 taken as the average of the six capital cities of Australia. The margin above the capital city prices therefore varies by some 400 per cent for the centres I have just referred. The district allowances assessed by the Western Australian Industrial Commission are $662 for Carnarvon and $2,047 for Kununurra. However, in respect of income tax zone allowances, the current situation is that all taxpayers residing in zone A, which includes both Carnarvon and Kununurra, receive the same allowance but as I said earlier, costs experienced can vary by at least 400 per cent. This situation is most inequitable and I believe demonstrates that the present zone allowances do not provide reasonable compensation for the costs and disabilities in either relative or absolute terms for people living in various locations within the zones. Furthermore, there are anomalies in respect of centres outside the present zone B boundary which experience costs and conditions at least equal to and in certain instances in excess of some centres within both zone A and zone B . The conclusion that must be drawn is that the two-zone approach is entirely inadequate for the conditions applying today.

I commend the Government for taking the initiative and increasing certain zone allowances for the first time in over 20 years. However, I express my disappointment that there has not been a thorough reform in a practical way of zone allowances. As I have already said this legislation takes no proper cognisance of the varying costs and considerations within the isolated parts of Australia which call for varying zone rebates. No consideration appears to have been given to pensioners and low income earners whose incomes fall below the tax threshold and who receive no benefit at all from a taxation rebate. Finally, no serious attempt seems to have been made to correct the very real cost differences between people living in metropolitan areas and those in isolated parts of Australia. In my view Australia will grow, flourish and develop to the benefit of all Australians only if governments are prepared to acknowledge the need to decentralise our community and to give its citizens an incentive to move into the high-cost, harsh environment of our outback.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some remarks on two aspects of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1982 which is now before the Senate. First, I greatly commend the Government in the areas of tax deductible gifts wherein measures are undertaken to allow deductions for gifts to three Polish relief funds by way of extending the range of organisations to which Australians can contribute relief funds and thereby obtain a deduction. The Australian people have always had a very close association with the people of Poland. One recalls that in 1794 the great revolutionary hero Kosciusko returned to his country of Poland in order to attempt to throw off the shackles of Russian oppression that existed even then. His peasant troops were armed with nothing but scythes on the top of wooden shafts. It is no wonder that our most noble peak in Australia is named after that revolutionary hero. I believe it symbolises the bonds that exist between the Australian and Polish peoples and which, as I say, is strengthened yet again by means of our taxation laws in this regard.

SPEECH.PARA: There can be no doubt that in making humanitarian aid available to the Polish people, particularly after the bitterly cold winter that they have just come through, we in Australia will be aiding the political movement to make spring an expression of democratic freedoms for which the Polish people so desperately long. There can be no doubt that in this provision of the taxation legislation we are not, in the normal way, providing humanitarian relief, though that must remain a dominant consideration. Food and medical supplies need to be provided to the people of Poland impoverished, as they have been, by an industrial and agricultural system that has collapsed and by the fact that their great coal export earning industry has collapsed along with everything else. That is the basis for them to earn revenue to purchase necessary foodstuffs and medical supplies abroad.

Anything we can do to aid the Polish people in their desperate plight must be welcomed, but there is the further dimension that in helping these people to survive we are indeed keeping alive the embers of the democratic movement in Poland. It is a revolution of the people which commands our support. It is evidently democratic in the tens of millions of people who have been attracted to the Solidarity banners, be they of the industrial politariat or the peasants of Poland in the farming wing of Solidarity. They formed Solidarity against the will of the party, against the will of the state. In fact, by acting so courageously they have demonstrated, paradoxically, that Marx was correct when he said that the working people, be they the industrial working class or the peasants, will throw off the shackles of their oppressors and humanise their own lives by courageously taking their future into their own hands. Of course, that is what has happened. As far as the ordinary people of Poland are concerned the state has no legitimacy. The party is left as an organisation which makes arrogant claims to act on behalf of, and to be the vanguard of, the politariat. However it is the people themselves, whether industrial workers or peasants, who will determine the future of Polish society. As I say, I commend the Government for extending those tax deduction provisions relating to gifts to organisations aiding the Polish people in the way in which it has been done.

Certain attempts are being made by the legislation before us to grapple with the transfer pricing policies, as they are colloquially characterised as, of certain multinational enterprises which operate within Australia. Transfer pricing is perhaps too simple and too small a segment of the range of practices that we are dealing with to really merit its constant use in this sort of discussion but it is one that has come into common use to describe the range of arrangements whereby multinational enterprises, acting as they may across many national borders, so manipulate their arrangements as to minimise the tax payable in country A, where perhaps the tax rates are higher than in country B, where they purport to pay most of their tax.

I was very pleased, I must say, and brought up with a bit of surprise to see, in the second reading speech of the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), the phrase 'international profit shifting arrangements'. I think if we had the term 'profit shifting arrangements' more constantly before us we would have a clearer grasp of what is going on. Transfer pricing practices are, of course, merely a mechanism to that end. Transfer pricing practices are just one aspect of the use by multinational enterprises of their tremendous capacity to shift profits around the world to tax havens or such locations as will enable them to pay the least amount of their moneys into the treasuries of those countries within which they operate. I wonder where the phrase 'profit shifting practices or arrangements' came from. Did it come from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development? In 1979 that Organisation, through its Committee on Fiscal Affairs, presented a report which expresses the concern of those countries-members of the OECD-in which multinational companies have this practice. The problem is well described in that document. It describes how a multinational enterprise can undertake many transactions between members of the group. As the contents show, it is not restricted to the transfer of goods or products in the physical sense. One can have a flow of technology or trade marks , the provision of certain management services or the provision of loans all in addition to the transfer of products or goods. In all of these cases the transfer of such technology, or the provision of services or the making available of loan moneys can be an occasion for manipulating a transaction so that the least amount of tax possible is paid in the host country of Australia, in our instance. The scope of this international phenomenon with which the OECD countries are concerned can be gained from reading the 1979 report of the OECD Committee, which stated:
. . . approximately 40% of imports to the United States in 1974 were intra-firm transactions . . . Roughly 50% of the United States exports in 1970 were within transnational corporate systems.

That gives some indication of the amount of international trade from that great trading power which is conducted within these multinational enter- prises. As I say, we are not merely dealing with the sale of goods but with a whole range of other transactions within multinational enterprises. I mention loans in particular because-I am sure if Senator Watson were here he would recall some of the evidence that was given to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources in relation to its inquiry into the aluminium industry in Australia-it is to the advantage of the parent company of a subsidiary operating in Australia to make moneys available to the Australian branch of this multinational enterprise by way of loan rather than equity contribution. The tax paid on dividends remitted to the parent company abroad is considerably higher than is the case if interest on loans is remitted abroad to that parent company.

It is a nice question to ask whether some equity contributions are disguised as loans. I hope that this legislation enables the Commissioner of Taxation to disentangle the myth from the reality and enables him to see clearly that a financial contribution from a parent company is indeed an equity contribution although it may be disguised as a loan. In other words, I hope that it will enable the Commissioner to say whether interest payments abroad are in fact dividends remitted abroad and ought to bear a tax accordingly. No doubt the Minister, whose interest and expertise in this matter is well known to the chamber, will be able to satisfy me on that matter.

What I am pleased to see is that in the new section 136AA the interest rates will be dealt with in the same way as the pricing arrangements-the contracts for sale of goods. In other words, if a multinational enterprise parent company made moneys by way of loan available to the Australian subsidiary at a rate of interest which was nowhere near that which would be expected to result from an arms-length negotiation by the Australian subsidiary with an overseas banker or other lending institution, the Taxation Commissioner would be able to substitute an arms-length interest rate for that which is set down as the interest rate by way of the legal documentation. This seems to be a very important advance in this legislation. It not only makes quite clear that we are concerned with the transfer of goods abroad that takes place under unrealistic terms of a contract for sale but also defines the word 'property' in such a way as to include any chose in action; any estate interest, right or power, whether at law or in equity, in or over property; any right to receive income; and any services.

Included in the definition of 'services' is the performance of professional or managerial tasks and an agreement for or in relation to the lending of moneys. Almost the full scope of those sorts of profit shifting arrangements which can occur in multinationals is covered by proposed section 136AA.

My interest in this area of our fiscal arrangements was triggered by my time spent on the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources looking into the bauxite, alumina and aluminium industries. Whilst it is quite a time that the OECD countries have been concerned in general with this matter, at least since the 1979 financial committee's report, I have no doubt that what triggered the exasperation of the Australian Government and Parliament with the operation of section 136 was the case in which Comalco Ltd successfully defended itself against the Commissioner of Taxation's attempt to impute to it the taxable income which it said it had not earned because of a very artificial method of transferring profits abroad. The particular High Court case was concerned with marketing arrangements in relation to bauxite sold to two Japanese companies through a Hong Kong subsidiary jointly owned by Comalco and the Japanese purchasers. The price of bauxite sold to the Hong Kong company by Comalco was lower than the price at which the same bauxite was then sold to the Japanese purchaser. It was claimed in evidence before us that the principal purpose of the arrangement was to gain access to the Japanese markets. However, it certainly had the additional effect, to put it no higher, of reducing tax payable in Australia, though not by overly significant amounts. It is estimated that the sum involved for 1979-80 was $150,000. Nevertheless, when one looks at the evidence brought into the High Court-I have the relevant exhibits-one finds that exhibit 7 in the case is an internal memorandum of 11 June 1963 of Comalco Industries Pty Ltd from Mr E. T. Biggs, who, I think, was the manager of the international division, in which he says, amongst other things, that he explained to a Japanese involved that:
. . . we had chosen Hong Kong as the location as this would give the maximum tax advantage over the dividends which they draw from the sales company.

Again, in exhibit 8 in the High Court case one finds a letter from Mr Christie, the managing director of Commonwealth Aluminium Corporation Pty Ltd, to Mr Shioya, managing director of Sumitomo Chemical Co. Ltd, stating, amongst other things:

Comalco has selected Hong Kong as the location for the sales company as the Hong Kong corporation tax, at 12 1/2 per cent, is very much lower than the corporation tax in either Australia or Japan and taxes of the profits to be shared can thus be minimised to the mutual benefit of both Comalco and the Japanese participating companies.

I am pleased to see that the very able chairman of that Senate Committee, Senator Andrew Thomas of Western Australia, nods in agreement that the Committee was right in coming to the conclusion that we had exposed on the Senate record this particular form of profit shifting arrangement. I note with pleasure that the legislation no longer requires that entering into the transaction for the purpose of defeating taxation need be proved as a dominant purpose. It is enough that in fact the effect is to shift profits out of Australia and then the terms of the legislation come into effect.

I might also say that I believe that this legislation in part owes its appearance in the Parliament to the work of that Committee. I think it was certainly one of the catalysts which, along with the general exasperation with the High Court in that decision, brought this legislation before us. Insofar as some will say that too much discretion is vested in the Commissioner of Taxation by this legislation, I answer that the High Court has created that situation for the Australian body politic. Mr Justice Murphy in the Westraders case said, I think very aptly:

. . . strictly literal interpretation of a tax act is an open invitation to artificial and contrived tax avoidance. Progress towards a free society will not be advanced by attributing to Parliament meanings which no one believes it intended so that income tax becomes optional for the rich while remaining compulsory for most income earners. If strict literalism continues to prevail the legislature may have no practical alternative but to vest tax officials with more and more discretion. This may well lead to tax laws capable, if unchecked, of great oppression.

The fact is, of course, that these discretions, such as they are, vested in the Commissioner of Taxation are appealable. There are guidelines set down by the Parliament in these sections which do not mean, by any means, that he has some sort of untrammelled discretion. But insofar as the movement is that way, as I say, it is largely the necessary response of this Parliament to the way in which the High Court has dealt with our legislation over the last few years. I could go on for some time on this subject, but I see that Senator Evans and other honourable senators are anxious to speak.

I simply wish to express my concern with the penalty provisions within the legislation. Whilst this may be properly dealt with at the Committee stage, I may not be speaking at that time, so I thought I would say now that the penalty clause provision of 10 per cent is really no penalty at all. I see it as doing no more than levying some sort of interest charge of 10 per cent for the amount of tax avoided. All it means, at the very most, is that moneys due to the Federal revenue will not be eroded by inflation, assuming an inflation rate of about 10 per cent. It does no more than that. It is certainly not a penalty from the point of view of the company involved. It merely puts the Federal revenue in the same position in real terms as if the moneys had been paid as they ought to have been. It possibly does not even do that, when one considers that the company had the use of that money and could certainly have invested it on the short term money market at twice that rate of interest. Certainly it will have used it, if not on the short term money market, within the internal affairs of the company to its advantage, which would certainly be greater than 10 per cent per annum. Otherwise, it probably would choose to pay the tax. When one calls this 10 per cent payment a penalty and then looks at other penalties levied in the tax Act, the claim that really there is a penalty involved becomes all the more ludicrous.

I will point to a few examples of much more severe penalties. Section 226 (1) provides a penalty of additional tax equal to the tax assessable-that is, a penalty of 100 per cent, not 10 per cent-for any taxpayer who fails to furnish any return or information required by the Act or by the Commissioner of Taxation . Section 226 (2) provides a penalty of double the tax sought to be avoided for any person omitting assessable income or claiming a rebate or deduction in excess of the expenditure actually incurred. Section 226 (2) (a) provides for a 200 per cent penalty for persons caught evading tax by the new general anti- avoidance section 177 which we enacted last year. When one compares the 10 per cent called for in this case with that range of penalties one sees that it is no more than levying of interest to keep the real value of the money up with an expected inflation rate of about 10 per cent. However, having expressed my disappointment with that particular aspect, and mindful of the second reading amendment and of the amendments that will be moved by the Opposition at the Committee stage, this proposed new section 136 represents a very necessary response by this Government and this Parliament to the practice of profit shifting by multinational enterprises. To that extent I certainly welcome it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to deal with only one part of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1982-that relating to the accelerated depreciation allowances in relation to the iron and steel industry. The amending legislation raises the whole subject of the Government's support for industry in this country-the Government's industry development policy. It raises questions of whether one-off changes in relation to a particular industry are good policy, particularly when at the same time the Government is announcing an Industries Assistance Commission inquiry into certain budgetary assistance to industry, bearing in mind that there are already IAC references on approaches to general reductions in protection levels and also on export incentives. It questions whether certain industries are favoured at the expense of others. As the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) reminded the Melbourne Chamber of Commerce in September of last year:

SPEECH.PARA: The farm plant and equipment can generally be written off over five years whereas depreciation life for most manufacturing plant ranges from six to 20 years.

If that principle can be supported, is the decision as to preference soundly based? Is the form of support, within the fiscal context, that attracting the greatest community benefit for the community cost involved? That is, is a depreciation allowance the best solution or would an investment allowance or some other form of incentive be better? If one looks beyond the taxation context , do the depreciation allowances match up against such non-tax incentives as export grants?

I will show that the consideration of accelerated depreciation allowances in industry in Australia is a worthwhile exercise. Within that concept-that is, within the general principle-I applaud the new provisions offered to the iron and steel industry. I must say, however, that I am concerned that it is a one- off measure and that the Government has not given reasons why it has decided to assist this industry at this time by this method. It makes evaluation of the assistance, as opposed to other forms of assistance, difficult. I hope that the Minister later in the debate will give reasons as to why the choice was made in this way. I trust that it will indicate a trend in the Government's industrial development policy towards greater and accelerated depreciation allowances. Nevertheless, the Government in so acting has indicated that the measure falls within its industry development policy. The objective of that policy, which I applaud, is sustained, strong, real economic growth. Without that we cannot sustain increases in living standards in this country, either through increased employment opportunities or increased material and non-material wants.

On an international comparison, I regret to say that we have not fared well on growth in the last decade. Australia's average gross domestic product growth rates in the 1970s were well below the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average and much lower than those of our Asian neighbours. Our standard of living has declined in relative terms. This raises the question: Why ? In the 1960s we had a period of relative stability for business. Inflation and interest rates were low and stable. Energy prices were stable. Exchange rates remained fixed for long periods. But the 1970s brought major changes. The first was a major shift in the direction of Australia's trade from the old world to the new world, from west to east, to countries which have more competitive and outward looking economies than Australia. This meant bilateral difficulties and associated questions of protection and industry assistance. Secondly, there was a rapid change of Government policy on private sector development and the difficulty of business in adapting.

A joint submission of five major mining and manufacturing companies to the Industries Assistance Commission recently pointed to 33 major taxation changes which affected the mining industry within the last decade. Given the lead times and the risks that are involved in that industry the difficulty of the industry in adapting is not surprising. A loss of confidence has resulted. Thirdly, and most important, the 1970s saw the emergence of historically high inflation rates with a whole new range of problems. These include: Erosion of capital through the taxation of illusory profits; increases in the real cost of money-that is, interest rates less inflation; increases in real wages without always having increases in productivity; reduced return on capital invested, loss of profitability; efforts to reduce outgoings; and growing unemployment.

With that experience the Government must look to what is necessary today in the 1980s for sustained, strong, economic growth. One important element of a growth- oriented policy would be an emphasis on broad measures that tend to lift productivity across a number of sectors. One step towards that policy could be the lifting of investment levels. I presume that that is at least one part of the rationale of the Government's decision in this part of the Bill. If that is correct and the Government's intention is to increase investment levels I commend it.

It is clear that budgetary assistance and appreciation is a method whereby governments can encourage greater investment. Additionally, more favourable tax treatments of capital lead to substantial competitive advantages in an open economy. This is because of the need to earn a lower pre-tax return to obtain the minimum return needed to recover the cost of using a capital asset. The Government gains not only a method of attracting new capital but also an opportunity of guiding that capital in a particular direction. The competitive advantages not only throughout Australia but also in an international trading environment in which we must survive and grow can lead to substantial capital movements between nations. I presume that that is another part of the rationale of the Government in relation to this proposed new section 57AK of the Act, to give the Australian steel industry some further international advantage.

In 1981, the Australian Industries Development Association had Arthur Andersen and Co. provide information on capital recovery allowances in 15 countries selected on the basis of their competitiveness with Australia. The results are most important because they indicate what we must compete against and the sort of advantage that we must consider giving if we are to attract sufficient investment to lift productivity and profitability across a number of sectors. Three major features came out of that survey distinguishing Australia from its competitors. The first related to depreciation on buildings and it is relevant to this debate because it shows another way in which the Government could have continued to give assistance to the iron and steel industry. It is a way that obviously is still open.

In 1972 an OECD survey of capital recovery allowances showed that Australia had the highest tax cost of buildings among the 22 member countries. The AIDA survey indicates that that still applies today. That 1981 survey found that the average period of depreciation write-off provided by the other 14 countries was 29 years . But it referred also to accelerated depreciation schemes for industrial buildings in Hong Kong, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan, the United Kingdom and the United States of America. The United Kingdom scheme allows a first year write-off of 75 per cent of expenditure incurred on buildings, industrial and mining but not commercial, after 10 March this year.

If we are to remain internationally competitive, and in order to sustain a growing industrial sector, the Government will have to give further consideration to the question of depreciation on industrial buildings.

The second major distinction that came out of the AIDA survey was the less than average depreciation rates that are allowed in Australia. With Australia's additional loading of 18 per cent on normal depreciation rates, which I might add does not apply to all plant and equipment, the survey indicates that we have an average write-off period of 6.9 years for manufacturing plant and equipment. That can be contrasted with a full first year write-off for plant and equipment in the United Kingdom and Malaysia; two years write-off in Canada for manufacturing, processing and mining equipment; and three years write-off in Singapore for plant and equipment. In summary, AIDA said:

Indeed if all the depreciation rates after allowing for accelerated depreciation are expressed in present value terms, the Australian rates would be among the lowest-(ie the most harsh) of the 15 countries.
Again, on normal rates on specific types of assets AIDA says in that survey:
The normal rates of depreciation in Australia are generally lower than our trading partners.

Perhaps even more important than the fact that our rates are low compared with our partners is the trend that is apparent from these recent surveys. Between 1980 and 1981 Hong Kong, Malaysia and Singapore introduced more favourable normal depreciation allowances. From 1981 substantially more favourable capital recovery assistance will be available in the United States. That trend must be something that is borne in mind by the Australian Government if, as I said, we are to remain competitive. To give credit where it is due, the Australian investment allowance is relatively generous with only six of the 15 countries having a more generous tax credit or investment allowance scheme. But the end result of the survey which is incorporated within a table showing the capital cost index in manufacturing, by country, is that our position with regard to incentive benefits of this type is extremely low.
