TALK.START.PARA: —As was said by AIDA:

SPEECH.PARA: A high tax cost of capital regime will induce less capital intensive and research and development intensive activities, the very industries which have the greatest potential for our region. Whereas overseas competitors will be induced to spend more on capital, similar industries in Australia will be accorded no such inducement.

What did the Myers Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia say on Australia's low depreciation rates as compared with its trading partners' rates? The Committee said that this suggests either that the effective working life of the assets is shorter-for technological and other reasons-overseas than in Australia or that the governments of the economies provide more attractive depreciation rates as an incentive to industrial investment. I suspect that both factors are, in fact, involved in the decisions overseas to have a more generous depreciation allowance.

In looking at the total package of government assistance-on the one hand protection, tariffs and quotas and on the other hand research and development grants, export incentives, taxation and budgetary assistance-I ask that the Government give serious consideration to accelerated depreciation not only in relation to the iron and steel industry, as it has been prepared to do in proposed new section 57AK of this Bill, but also across the industrial front. Firstly, I have no doubt that, in giving consideration to that request, the Government will bear in mind the reasoning of both the Asprey Taxation Review Committee and the Mathews Committee of Inquiry into Inflation and Taxation which is still valid, that is, that a taxation system which does not recognise the impact of inflation on the replacement of stocks and capital is not compatible with the continuity of sufficient business incentive. Accelerated depreciation offers some compensation in that aspect.

Secondly, I trust that the Government will bear in mind that more generous depreciation allowances will reduce the current distortion between the repairs and maintenance and new capital equipment mix. This distortion leads to more aged and inefficient plant than would otherwise be the case. That effects competitiveness and retards growth. In that regard it is interesting to note in another of the submissions to the inquiry-that of the Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia-that 78 per cent of machine tools used in Australia are more than 10 years old; 61 per cent of such tools in the US, Germany and Japan are less than five years old. I trust that the Government will take into account also the level of private sector investment in research in Australia which is comparatively low. Improved depreciation allowances and greater return on capital invested may well encourage a reversal of that trend. This would be highly satisfactory. I trust also that the Government will take into account that existing rates are not designed to take obsolescence into account. Industry must be able to respond quickly to changing technology if we are to remain competitive. I quote the Bureau of Industry Economics in a recent report on the impact of technological change in Australian industry. The report states:

. . . a selective or across the board policy of slowing the rate of technological change has the effect of making domestic costs higher than they would otherwise be, which in turn, serves to impair the long run growth opportunities in industry.

I presume that the Government will take into account also the very substantial increases in the cost of equipment and its installation due to inflation, that is, depreciation allowances based on historical costs. The real value of the depreciation deduction declines each year while the cost of replacing the asset increases.

Another point that I make on this subject of greater taxation and budgetary assistance to industry to enable Australia to increase its competitive status is that if we are to grow in this very competitive world our basic conservatism- which I think in many ways exists more strongly among members on the other side of the chamber-must be cast aside. We must look at the inducements available in countries; for example, tax holidays available to primary industries in Malaysia of six to 10 years, in Singapore of five to eight years, in Taiwan of five years and in South Korea of five years. Is it not therefore surprising that the growth within these economies is so rapidly overtaking our own? We must become more imaginative. We must become more radical. We must look to the ways in which we can compete more efficiently and more effectively so that we can, in fact, be ahead of some of our Asian competitors rather than follow behind them. The last point that I wish to make is that I urge government to look at the whole package . Whilst accepting the value to the steel industry I urge government in the future to steer away from one-offs, to give industry clear, consistent guidelines. Let it be obvious where particular government action falls within the total growth package.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1982, which, I am happy to say, the Australian Democrats support, will amend the income tax law in a number of very significant ways. As we have given an undertaking to the Government not to delay unnecessarily the workings of the Senate-in fact we have said that we will endeavour to expedite the passage of legislation through this chamber-I propose to confine myself to only two areas of this very comprehensive and important Bill, namely, the areas of transfer pricing and depreciation allowances. Perhaps, instead of transfer pricing, in deference to Senator Tate and to the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), I should say profit shifting arrangements. I think that was the term used. I agree that this is what we are talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: I will speak only briefly on depreciation because Senator Hill has covered that vitally important subject in an excellent manner. I recommend that the Senate read his comments. They should be studied very carefully. They are very vital as far as industry is concerned. We have spent so much time in this place and in public debate talking about free trade and the level of tariff protection that industry does or does not enjoy in Australia that we have forgotten the other very important incentives that are enjoyed by industries around the world which are Australia's industrial competitors. I will talk, then, on depreciation and underline some of the comments that Senator Hill made so well. The Australian Labor Party has circulated two sets of amendments. The first was moved to the motion that the Bill be read a second time and the second will be moved in the Committee stage. The Democrats wish to move an amendment to the Labor Party's second reading amendment. I move:
Leave out paragraph (c) of the words proposed to be added.

That amendment addresses itself to the issue of retrospectivity-an area that I wish to cover in some detail later in my remarks. The Democrats are absolutely opposed to retrospectivity in any shape or form, irrespective of whether it relates to our tax laws or to the laws of the land generally. I am anxious to make our position abundantly clear, as it seems to have caused some confusion in the Australian Labor Party. I thought that our leader, Senator Chipp, made the position abundantly clear during our election campaign, but as there is some confusion we will try to clarify the position so that all are clear as to where the Democrats stand on this vital matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had better have a look at your notice of motion today.

—A clause of this Bill allows the Commissioner of Taxation to counter transfer pricing arrangements and imposes a penalty of 10 per cent on companies found guilty of breaching the provision. The Democrats, I am happy to advise Senator Grimes, agree with the ALP that this penalty is ridiculously small. We support that part of the Labor Party's amendment which proposes to increase to 100 per cent the penalty on transfer pricing. If such an amendment were acted on by the Government it would have the effect of being a considerable disincentive for organisations to rip off Australians in the shameful way that has been the practice of so many transnational companies. This is an area that has cost the Australian Government millions and millions of dollars in revenue. It is now being addressed in this Bill, but in a very minor way. Transnationals would undoubtedly consider a 100 per cent penalty very carefully before embarking on schemes to avoid taxation in this country. So we urge the Government to strengthen those positions along the lines of the Australian Labor Party's amendment. I point out, as I think has already been made clear by Senator Tate, that the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, the United Nations and the International Labour Organisation-three very important organisations-have already addressed the problem of transfer pricing and have set out in great detail codes of conduct for transnational corporations . On taxation the OECD states:

SPEECH.PARA: Enterprises should

refrain from making use of the particular facilities available to them, such as transfer pricing which does not conform to an arm's length standard, for modifying in ways contrary to national laws the tax base on which members of the group are assessed.
That is one of the OECD guidelines. The United Nations has this to say about transfer pricing as it applies to taxation:
In their intracorporate transactions transnational corporations should not use pricing principles, which, contrary to national legislation . . .
It goes on to state:
In their intracorporate transactions transnational corporations should use pricing policies based on international market prices, or in the absence of such prices, the 'arm's length' principle.

. . . Under conditions and safeguards set forth in this Code, transnational corporations should disclose to the public the principles applied by them in transfer pricing and supply to Governmental authorities all relevant information related to transfer pricing.

If those two codes of conduct were incorporated in a code of conduct in Australia it would at least make clear to the transnational companies what the Government wants to happen. Until we make clear to transnational corporations what the law of the land is, what the will of the Government is in this respect, we cannot be critical of any taxation arrangements that they may enter into to minimise their taxation in this land. We have to make clear to transnationals what this Government wishes to happen. I wish to dwell briefly on the issue of retrospectivity insofar as the Labor Party's amendment is concerned. The amendment sets out to make the legislation retrospective to 1979. In this we cannot concur.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only in section 26AAA, not the lot.

—Yes, I understand that. As I said earlier, as a general principle the Australian Democrats are opposed to retrospectivity in any legislation. While we strongly endorse the Government's move to cut down on tax avoidance and tax evasion-we believe that the Australian Taxation Office should be strengthened in personnel so that it can attack this very important problem- we cannot agree that the tax law should be made retrospective under any circumstances. We believe that it is fair that the law should be made to operate from the time the Treasurer (Mr Howard) first announces that he intends to move against a certain tax avoidance scheme that has come to his notice. From the day he makes that announcemant we believe that people will be warned that the Government intends to do something. We believe that it is reasonable that any subsequent legislation which is introduced into this Parliament should date effectively from the date on which the Treasurer makes the first announcement.
—Provided that the intention is quite clear.

—Yes, it should date from the point at which he made his intention quite clear, even though the legislation may take a considerable time to be drafted and passed through the Parliament. We believe that this approach is reasonable and I am pleased to see that some Government senators at least are agreeing with the Democrats' approach on this matter. We will oppose those aspects of the Labor Party's amendments which ask the Government to impose legislation on this matter retrospective to 1979.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter I raise-I will deal with it very briefly because, as I said, it has been so well covered by Senator Hill-is depreciation. The Government foreshadowed in its Budget Papers that it intended to introduce legislation to cover this matter and that it would apply accelerated depreciation allowances for plant used to produce basic iron and steel first ordered under contracts entered into after 18 August 1981. The rate for eligible plant which currently has a write-off period for taxation purposes of five years or more will be 20 per cent of the capital cost of the plant, and plant which currently has a write -off period of less than five years will have an allowance of 33 1/3 per cent. Those special rates will apply to 30 June 1991. As we have heard, the Canadians, for instance, are prepared to allow plant-I understand it is all engineering plant-in Canada to be written off over a period of two years. Many countries allow plant to be written off over one year for taxation purposes. There is no doubt that Australian industry has suffered great stress over a period of some 10 years due to competition from imports and general economic conditions. Because of this long period of pressure it is true that many Australian industries have plant which is outdated. If we are to have a revival of efficient manufacturing in Australia we have to look quickly to the problem of modernising our plant. Added to this, a technological revolution is going on. If we do not address ourselves to the problem of modernising our plant we will be forgotten as an industrial nation for all time.

The rate of change of design and the things that can be done with machinery these days are quite amazing even to a person such as me who has been involved in engineering for over 35 years. We can now put drawings into a computerised machine and wait until the die, the final product, comes out at the other end, machined to the precise details of the drawings. The silicon chip is enabling the world to do this in machine design. If Australia does not keep up with this rapid improvement in machinery its industries will be doomed. We have to give industry the incentive to modernise. I can think of no better way of doing so than to allow for much quicker depreciation allowances than are currently allowed under the tax laws. Senator Hill also mentioned depreciation of buildings, another area in which Australia is very far behind what is now common practice in most Western industrialised countries.

I conclude by saying that we commend the Government for addressing in this Bill a number of very important questions. On the question of tax avoidance we say that it has not gone far enough and we will support the Labor Party on this issue. The Government has not gone far enough on the question of depreciation allowances. We hope that it will give both those areas its very careful attention during the framing of the 1982-83 Budget. I foreshadow that the Australian Democrats will vote against amendments (1), (2), (3), (4) and (5) that the Labor Party proposes to move during the Committee stage. Those five amendments relate to retrospectivity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The two central features of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1982 are those concerned with transfer pricing and tightening the capital gains provision in section 26AAA. I will confine my remarks to those topics. Let me say at the outset that this Bill represents another alarming example of the phenomenon we have seen so much of in recent years of massive additions being made to the statute book, with each new Bill adding multiple new pages to what is already a very massive Act. Clause 19 inserts the new Division 13 relating to transfer pricing. It amounts to 12 pages in place of the existing Division 13 which consists of a single section, the ill -fated section 136. The existing section 136, in its present form of twelve lines, having been rendered ineffective by the High Court of Australia in the Comalco case, has been replaced by provisions which extend over 12 pages. The clause 4 amendment to section 26AAA is, by contrast, less dramatic, containing only six pages. Still, the Bill as a whole rambles its way-understandably enough , given the drafting approach of the Government-across some 40 pages of new legislation. As my colleague in the other place, Mr Willis, counted, there have been about 40 taxing measures since 1976, adding 700 pages to the Income Tax Assessment Act which now consists of over 1,000 pages. There seems to be an urgent need for a comprehensive inquiry into the structure and form of the Act with a view to a complete rewrite, its simplification and consolidation for the obvious reasons that the more complex the Act, the harder it is for any taxpayer to know what his obligations are or for any legal practitioner to give accurate advice. More importantly, the denser the legislative jungle, the greater the scope for subtle avoidance schemes which manipulate the detailed provisions to produce a result other than that which was intended.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem, of course, lies not only in the text of the legislation but also in the approach to it of the courts and their tendency, talking about jungles, often to confuse the wood with the trees. We have called often enough for a departure from strict legalism in the application of the judicial task of statutory interpretation and the adoption of more purposive interpretations, taking a broader view of the mischief of the tax avoidance which the various provisions are designed to overcome. That approach, which the Australian Labor Party has long been espousing, is now apparently beginning to bear some fruit. We are certainly heartened by the recent legislative developments, which have either occurred or been foreshadowed by the present Government, involving section 15AA of the Acts Interpretation Act, directing the judges to follow out a purposive interpretation where the circumstances allow it. We are also moved a little by the recent decisions of the High Court in the Cooper Brookes case and in Whitford's Beach case, both of which indicated a changing attitude on the part of the High Court-an attitude not simply founded on the legislative direction now given the High Court by section 15AA.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have a greater faith in the integrity of the judges than I have.

—That may be so. They cannot, of course, work without the tools that are given to them by the legislature, however well motivated, however keen they may be to do real justice and not the kind of justice that we may have seen in some notorious cases in recent years. From that point of view we regard it as incumbent upon the legislature to go further in its approach to dealing with tax avoidance and evasion than has been the case so far. Among the approaches that we have suggested and will be suggesting again, no doubt, are the insertion of specific objects clauses into the various parts of taxation legislation so that judges and, for that matter, taxpayers are left in no doubt as to what the mischief is that the legislation is being directed at, a technique which would undoubtedly enhance the use of a more purposive interpretation by the courts.

SPEECH.PARA: The other more far reaching legislative tool that we have constantly urged should be used in appropriate cases is the weapon of retrospective legislation. I will have a little more to say about that in a moment, particularly in the light of Senator Siddons's comments. I will say something, firstly, of a more technical nature about the particular transfer pricing provisions contained in this Bill, provisions which are rather more aptly named-as Senator Tate said-by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle as the profit shifting provisions or the provisions to deal with profit shifting arrangements. The nature of these arrangements has already been described in very considerable detail by not only my colleagues, Senator Walsh and Senator Tate, but also, in greater detail still , by Mr Willis in the other place. It is-I need say no more-a massive area of revenue loss. We certainly welcome the amendments which are here contained. The particular features that we most welcome are, firstly, the wide discretions that are vested in the Commissioner of Taxation, an acknowledgment that we cannot afford to tie the Commissioner's hands when he confronts sophisticated tax avoiders, operating in the twilight zone of commercial arrangements such as are involved in transfer pricing. The Labor Party called for wider discretions to be vested in the Commissioner in dealing with these ambiguous areas of tax avoidance when Part IVA was debated some months ago. We will continue to call for it as an appropriate legislative weapon in these sorts of situations where the transactions in question are not easily labelled on their face as contrived tax avoidance arrangements, but may wear all the garments of a legitimate commercial transaction and have some commercial legitimacy about them. In these circumstances it is a matter for the Commissioner weighing and balancing a variety of factors to determine whether, in all the circumstances of the case, there has indeed been an avoidance situation.

We acknowledge that in many other areas of tax legislation it is not appropriate for the Commissioner to have vested in him wide-ranging discretions- on the general principle that taxpayers should know, with as much certainty as is humanly possible, what their liability is likely to be. But when we are talking about very large sums of money being lost to revenue through the operation of what I have described as ambiguous or twilight zone tax avoidance arrangements, of which transfer pricing is a pretty classic example, the vesting of wide discretions of this kind seems to be the only possible legislative technique available. We welcome its application.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think this legislation will be effective in preventing that?

—I think it will be a darn sight more effective than the odds and ends provisions which have been around for the Commissioner to use hitherto in relation to transfer pricing. I think it would be likely to be more effective were the penalty provisions to be beefed up rather more substantially and were there to be deterrent effects of that kind. But that apart, I doubt that very much more could have been done. However I think the legislation, in vesting the very wide discretions that are vested in the Commissioner, could have given itself a greater chance of success were there to be more specific legislative guidelines set out as to the criteria to be applied by him.

SPEECH.PARA: The crucial element that is in this part of the Bill is the notion of arm's- length consideration and the determination of arm's-length consideration by the Commissioner. We believe that it might be easier for everyone involved to have a better idea as to what arm's-length consideration might be held to be if there were some statutory criteria listed in the Bill having regard to things such as, for example-I do not state these with any precision-the corporate structure and the relationship to each other of the various parties concerned in the transaction, the consideration received or perceivable in respect of comparable transactions and the cost of the supply or acquisition of the property or comparable property in comparable cases. There are many other criteria of that kind that one could articulate. But I think if that sort of thing were set out in the Bill it would make these provisions a little more practically able to be enforced, maybe because there would be more compliance at the outset by the parties because they would be able to understand the kind of considerations that the Commissioner is likely to apply.

The other drafting thing that we applaud about section 136, as it now appears before us, is that these provisions are not limited by any requirement that tax avoidance be the dominant purpose of the transaction. That is important because in so many of these twilight zone commercial transactions where there is at least some commercial justification for what is going on it is difficult, obviously, to establish that the tax avoidance purpose is the dominant one. It is enough that it be one, one might say, for the Commissioner to be able to move in this area. That was a view that we took, without success, in the context of the debate on Part IVA. We note that the Government does seem to have accepted the force of this argument in the present context.

But let me add to those minor bits of applause some statement of concern about the deficiencies in the Bill. Primarily, they go to the penalties. Clause 23 amends section 226 to provide that the additional tax which is payable in the case of a transaction found to be one of transfer pricing is to be calculated at a rate of 10 per cent per annum in respect of the specified period; that is, between the last date for furnishing the relevant return and the date on which the assessment is made. That 10 per cent rate is applied to the amount of tax avoided. But, of course, it is 10 per cent per annum, so if the period were less than one year the penalty would be even less than 10 per cent of the amount of the tax avoided-even less than the rate of inflation. One can, I think, ask quite properly what kind of penalty that is. It does not really amount to anything more than ensuring, as Senator Tate said, that the amount of primary tax due to the Government is not in fact seriously eroded through inflation over time. The rate of penalty is no more than that applicable under section 207 of the Act where tax remains unpaid after the due date. It is hard to credit that the Government regards this as a serious or appropriate deterrent to transfer pricing arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—It does look to us, as apparently it does to Senator Chipp, like merely tickling with a feather, a proposal from a government which simply is not prepared to deal firmly with large transnational corporations. What sort of a disincentive can a 10 per cent penalty be when the taxpayer can reinvest the tax avoided at, in many cases, around 20 per cent nowadays in the meantime? The Labor Party thinks it is simply another example of a government which is all appearance and no substance when it comes to combating tax avoidance. This is one of the matters that we will be picking up, with it appears the Democrats' support, in the Committee stage. We certainly appreciate that support and the reasons for it that have been articulated by Senator Siddons.

SPEECH.PARA: One further technical point that needs to be made very briskly about section 136 is that there is a doubt which remains in the minds of many lawyers, to which the Government perhaps ought to have some regard, as to whether Division 13, as the explanatory memorandum says, will apply comprehensively in the international field and to the exclusion of section 31C and the relevant sub- division of Division 2, they being provisions which enable the Commissioner to deem the extent of consideration where there is no bona fide transaction. They are provisions which have been thought to have some relevance to transfer pricing situations in the past.

All that is said in section 136AB (2) and section 136AE (9) is that in the application of Division 13 the operation of each of the other provisions is to be disregarded. But that does not prevent those provisions from being applied to the transactions in question. There is a danger, I guess, that if those other provisions were still applicable the court or Commissioner may be moved to regard them as the appropriate weapons to deal with a particular transfer pricing situation rather than the slightly more draconian provisions that are being introduced in Division 13 of this bill.

Section 26AAA is the capital gains provision. We acknowledge the fact that section 26AAA is, and always has been since its introduction in 1973-whatever semantic games the present Treasurer (Mr Howard) might care to play with it-a short term capital gains tax provision. We have in clause 4 of this Bill an attempt to cover a loophole which has become apparent in the operation of section 26AAA what we might call the Holmes aCourt-Bond amendment. To appreciate what this amendment is all about I think one needs do no more than quote from the language of the explanatory memorandum which explains succinctly what the problem is and what the new clause is proposing to do about it. The explanatory memorandum states:

As presently framed, section 26AAA taxes profits arising from the sale of property within 12 months of its purchase by the taxpayer. However, the intention of the law may be avoided by arranging for a private company to purchase property and then, within 12 months, selling controlling shares in the company at a price which reflects the increase in value of the underlying property.

I interpolate that this is, of course, what happened in the notorious Bell and Bond cases-three of them since 1979-when, in each case, after takeover enterprises a very handsome profit was accomplished by the companies in question , not by simply realising that profit in the ordinary way but by selling the whole of the companies in question with shares at an inflated value to represent that profit. The memorandum continues:

The technique could be varied by using a trust as the vehicle for the purchase and sale of assets, or by holding an interest in property through a chain of companies, or through interposed companies, partnerships or trusts.

To remedy the defect, the amendment will specify that a taxpayer is to be assessed to tax where he sells shares in a private (unlisted) company or an interest in a private trust estate if, at the time of the sale, the company or trustee owns property that was purchased by it within the preceding 12 months and the value of which is not less than 75 per cent of the net worth of the company or trust estate.

In those circumstances, the taxpayer's assessable income will include so much of the sale price of the shares or the interest in the trust estate as reflects an increase in the value of the underlying property from the time it was purchased to the time when the shares or interest were sold by the taxpayer. An appropriate allowance will be made in respect of any additional expenditure incurred in relation to the property during that period.

That is a fine provision as far as it goes in that explanation of it thoughtfully provided by the Government and, clearly, it will do the job in catching for the future the transactions that have aroused so much, I think, legitimate indignation in the media and elsewhere over the last three years. But what it will not, of course, do as it is cast at the moment is reach backwards so as to cover the particular transactions that have caused all the fuss, the details of which I do not think it is really necessary for me to spell out because that job has been done amply well by other speakers. However, I will say that what we are talking about is the Bell takeover bid for Ansett in 1979 which resulted in the group selling off the shares through a subsidiary company and making a tax-free profit of $11m. In March of 1981 the same Bell group made a takeover raid for Elder Smith Goldsbrough Mort Ltd and acquired a substantial number of shares in that company. It eventually abandoned the attempt and sold off the shares by selling the subsidiary company and making a profit of $16.5m, again tax free as section 26AAA now stands. The third example is the Bond Corporation with its takeover bid for White Industries Ltd in August 1980 which involved a tax free profit of around $32m. Adding the amounts of the profit and making the appropriate calculations we see that we are talking about a loss to revenue in those three notorious transactions alone of something like $27m.

Our solution, which has been foreshadowed, is to make this amendment to section 26AAA retrospective in its application. What is the justification for doing that ? Let me spell out again what the Labor Party is and is not saying about retrospective legislation to deal with tax avoidance legislation. I have done this job before, on 12 September 1979 in the Senate and also on 11 June 1981, at fairly nauseous length. I do not want to go over it at such great length again. There is perhaps one further threshold point. We are talking about not just retrospectivity back to the date of an announcement by the Treasurer of an intention to legislate because in a situation where everybody is clearly on notice that is the kind of limited retrospectivity which the Treasurer has been applying now for a number of years and about which nobody is seriously unhappy. What we are talking about is retrospective legislation reaching back rather further than that; back to the first known date of operation of the avoidance scheme in question; back to the first known time that it has operated, even if the scheme in question remains hidden from public view, from the Treasurer's view and from the Taxation Office's view for maybe one year, two years, three years or even longer after that. The justification for-

TALK.START.PARA: —How long? Do you put a limit on it?

—I think the limit arises naturally from the nature of the criteria which I will now seek to articulate. But basically I think nowadays we are not talking about anything going back much beyond the last two, three or four years at most because all the really rough schemes that appeared during the 1970s-I think it has been acknowledged that they really only started to appear on any major scale around perhaps 1974-75-have now been legislated against in this piecemeal fashion by the Government's 40-odd remedial measures over the last five or six years. We are talking about only a handful of roughies-if I may so describe them-which have not yet been picked up. I would put the Bell and Bond cases in that category and further examples of schemes that may be created in the future but which are of a nature that they are likely to remain disguised from the Taxation Office until the second year or so of their operation. So I say to Senator Chipp that I do not think it really involves reaching right back into the dim, dark past. Certainly I would not be comfortable about applying even the principles I will now spell out to further back than two, three or four years at the most.

SPEECH.PARA: The object of legislating in this way is, of course, that it is notoriously the most effective deterrent of all. We do not have to worry about the multiple pages of legislation to cover every known, conceivable loophole that reveals itself because once we demonstrate a clear-cut legislative intention to legislate retrospectively so that we wipe out back to day one whatever benefit the tax avoider got from his ill-gotten activity we make it very clear to that tax avoider that any future scheme into which he might enter will be subjected to exactly the same kind of treatment and that he will not derive any benefit at all from engaging in the avoidance arrangement. At the moment taxpayers are getting a free go, as one can describe it, for at least a year or so for most of these highly complex, artificial avoidance schemes simply because it takes that long for the Commissioner of Taxation to catch up with what is going on.

What we are basically saying about this legislation is that it should operate only in very limited and carefully defined circumstanes-only in relation to schemes which are unambiguously blatant, contrived and artificial and which would be so understood by everyone who had to look at them. We do not regard this kind of legislation as being appropriate in any way for ambiguous or twilight zone tax avoidance arrangements which may have a redeeming commercial justification as well as a tax avoidance justification. I draw a distinction in that respect between the kind of anti-tax avoidance measure that is involved in section 136 dealing with transfer pricing in which each such transaction may, as I said earlier in this speech, have a legitimate commercial content and some of the more hair-raising Curran-type contrived schemes.

This legislation can be appropriate only in respect of specifically identified schemes which are dealt with in very specifically drawn legislation. I think it is quite inappropriate for retrospective legislation of the kind I am talking about to apply in a discretionary context where the Commissioner can apply his own discretion, perhaps extending backwards for some years, to reconstruct transactions according to what he thinks the actual cash values or merits of the transactions were. It has to be the kind of transaction which nobody could conceivably have entered into with other than open eyes, realising it to be a kind of transaction which had no other justification in anybody's mind except that of tax avoidance.

Finally, it would be most inappropriate for such retrospective legislation to contain any penal content. We are not talking in any way about the retrospective application of penal provisions. We are talking only about the retrospective application of a liability to pay the basic marginal rate of tax that would otherwise have been applicable had the transaction been viewed in a different light at the time. I can appreciate the way in which the Democrats have been wrestling with the principles which are relevant to apply in this area. I notice that Senator Chipp in a notice of motion given on 29 April in fact indicated that one of the approaches that ought to be adopted was:

a systematic attack on tax avoidance schemes including retrospective application of new legislative measures following specific identification and warning of the types of schemes to be affected by the legislation.
Of course, Senator Chipp is referring to a prior warning. No doubt he is doing no more than referring to the existing practice of the Government. I do not read that as going any further than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage, but I may be persuaded to your point of view in the next Parliament if these provisions do not work.

—I am indebted to Senator Chipp for that intervention because it shows that he and, I hope, the rest of the Democrats have an open mind. In fact the Government, to some extent at least, has an open mind. It has always been my belief, as I said on 11 June, that the Treasurer's mind was still reasonably open on this matter but that he was having difficulty in persuading his Cabinet about the desirability of going that extra distance.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 February 1982 (Hansard, page 388,) Senator Button asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction, the following question without notice:

The Minister for Housing and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
There has been a decline in welfare housing funds for Victoria paid under the Housing Assistance Act, but the decline is not as dramatic as has been suggested.

Commonwealth welfare housing funds under the Housing Assistance Act in 1978-79 were $85.8m, of which about 4 per cent were in the form of grants. In 1981-82, the funds are $58.8m. It is important to note however, that non-repayable grants now comprise about 38 per cent of total funds, and the State can clearly direct these funds to the most needy. In this context it should be noted that Victoria has taken steps to get more value for money and to more efficiently assist greater numbers of people in need. In conjunction with building societies, the State is operating an interest subsidy scheme to provide low interest loans to home buyers. It has also stopped large scale land development and it has significantly increased spot purchasing to boost the rental stock.

When other Commonwealth housing and accommodation payments are taken into account, the estimated expenditure for Victoria in 1981-82 is $149.9m compared with $116.9m in 1980-81, an increase of 21.44 per cent. Areas of significant increase include allocations under the Aged and Disabled Persons' Homes Act, increased from $6.0m to $10.9m; estimated expenditure on supplementary rental assistance to pensioners, increased from $23.0m to $29.0m; and estimated expenditure on home savings grants, increased from $13.2m to $24.0m.
I am aware of newspaper reports of such a document. However, I regard the matter as being completely the responsibility of the State Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 March 1982 (Hansard, page 782) Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the following question without notice:

The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following additional information to the reply I gave to the honourable senator's question:

The Australian Development Assistance Bureau (ADAB) makes maximum possible use of specialist resources in the identification and design of projects as well as in the management and implementation of Australian aid projects. These are private sector consulting firms, public sector authorities and individual experts. These organisations or individuals are in most instances selected on a competitive basis to ensure that the best quality and most appropriate services are obtained. Contractual agreements are negotiated with ADAB which, inter alia , specify the scope of their services, the estimated cost and the format of their financial and progress reports.

Project performance and progressive expenditure are closely monitored by officers in the Bureau. Where the Bureau lacks particular technical expertise to monitor effectively or review performance, it is able to draw on expert professional advice from appropriate technically oriented public or private sector organisations.

I should add that the objectives, achievements and expenditure patterns of all our larger aid projects are also closely examined as part of a regular review/ evaluation process which is administered by a team of experienced officers in the Bureau's Appraisal and Evaluation Unit. Such reviews are undertaken jointly or in close collaboration with relevant recipient government authorities. The Australian review teams usually include appropriate professional technical experts engaged under contract for this purpose from both public and private sector organisations. These are major assignments which are undertaken on site. Team members are required to examine and report on a project's past achievements and if appropriate to recommend changes to its objectives, level and nature of Australia's contribution and also its duration.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 March 1982 (Hansard, page 859) Senator MacGibbon asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning recent tests on cattle held at Cocos Island animal quarantine station.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:
Of the first consignment of cattle to be imported through the Cocos Island animal quarantine station 50 were released at the end of the quarantine period.

The results of the series of tests performed on the other six animals while in the Cocos Island animal quarantine station clearly indicate that they have been exposed to epizootic haemorrhagic disease virus. This was despite their having passed an extensive series of tests for this disease both on-farm and in pre- embarkation quarantine in Canada.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Housing and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The campaign was handled by the Australian Government Advertising Service ( AGAS) which has responsibility for engaging advertising agencies, and purchasing advertising space for Commonwealth departments.

Scheduling of the advertisements and decisions on the amount and percentage of expenditure between the States and Territories were made by AGAS with the aim of ensuring satisfactory and effective communication with the Australian public .
The campaign was handled by AGAS in its usual efficient and professional way to achieve Australia-wide public awareness within the given advertising budget.
AGAS has advised the Department of Housing and Construction that the campaign costs were as follows:
$ television time 178,994 daily Press space 79,200 ethnic Press 10,157 total media expenditure 268,351
Other items such as production costs and service fees amounted to $31,649.

Of the total expenditure on television time and Press space 34.6 per cent was spent in New South Wales, 33.2 per cent in Victoria, 9.7 per cent in Queensland , 7.7 per cent in South Australia, 6.3 per cent in Western Australia, 1.2 per cent in Tasmania, 0.4 per cent in the Northern Territory and 1.2 per cent in the Australian Capital Territory. A further 5.7 per cent was expended on national and ethnic Press.

Initially it was expected that advertising costs on television in Victoria would be higher than in New South Wales as the Victorian stations had offered more prime time (and therefore more expensive) spots. In the event, more was spent on television in New South Wales than in Victoria.

The following figures were provided by AGAS to the Department of Housing and Construction relating to the campaign. The figures show that over one third of expenditure in Victoria took place after the elections in that State.

The fact that the Department of Housing and Construction received some 32,600 telephone calls around Australia in the three weeks following the Treasurer's announcement of the Government's new housing policies is proof of the wide interest people had in the matter. Taxation offices no doubt received many other calls from people seeking information.

The Government's advertising campaign used television spot advertisements as pointers to detailed Press notices. It is reasonable to assume that many other people had intended to ask questions by phone, but in fact had their queries answered by the detailed information carried in the Press notices.

As far as the overall campaign is concerned, I am informed that the advertising industry would not regard $300,000 as an unusually large amount to spend in order to achieve a moderate level of public awareness nationwide. I am convinced that the expenditure was fully justified as a means of ensuring the public of Australia were informed about their entitlements under the government's new housing policies.

The attached data on their aid efforts are DAC Secretariat estimates collected from a variety of sources and established in collaboration with experts in DAC member countries. TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 March 1982 (Hansard, page 1089), Senator Evans asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Government directed Telecom Australia to reduce its staff this financial year by 2,000?
Will half this number of jobs be lost in Victoria?
Is this due to the particularly depressed condition of the Victorian economy, both in absolute terms and comparatively with other States?
Is it the case that Victoria is the only mainland State in which Telecom plans to reduce its level of investment in new works and services in the 1981-82 financial year?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:
Telecom has been required to reduce its staff by 2,000 this financial year.
Approximately 1,000 of the reduction will be in Victoria.

The higher savings are achievable in Victoria due to a levelling of demand in that State. A similar situation is not evident in other States. Demand is particularly high in Queensland and there is difficulty in recruiting suitably qualified staff. Telecom has therefore invited lines staff in Victoria to move to Queensland to relieve pressure in the higher demand areas.
Telecom's engineering construction program provides for increased expenditure in all States in 1981-82.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 March 1982 (Hansard, page 1159), Senator Coates asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, a question without notice concerning the broadcasting time slot of the Australian Broadcasting Commission's regional news bulletins on non-metropolitan television stations.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Communications has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The ABC advises that a change in the time slot for the evening regional television news throughout Australia is under consideration, but that no firm decision has been made. The decision is one for senior management, in consultation with the ABC's branches and having regard to the viewing habits of people in country areas.
